summary: Since childhood, it was always hard for me to make friends. People who I liked I pushed hard to be friends with, but I guess I came across as too clingy . Now I see the same thing happening with my 7-year-old son. When his cousins or my cousins’ kids come and he plays with them, he wants to maintain friendships .

title: Asking Eric: I understand companies want employees to ‘be friendlier,’ but I find it intrusive
text: Dear Eric: Many companies are training their employees to “be friendlier.” Now, when I go to pay for my groceries or have bloodwork done at a lab, someone invariably asks me, “so what are you doing the rest of your day?” I find that to be very intrusive from someone I don’t know and may never see again. I understand they have been trained so it isn’t necessarily their fault, but I need a better response than “who wants to know?” or “why are you asking me this?” – Trying to Keep Boundaries Dear Boundaries: Something general and meaningless can help divert small talk such as this. “Oh, not sure” or “enjoying it, I hope” or “this and that.” These are empty calorie phrases that keep the ball in the air without forcing you to divulge anything you don’t want to divulge. It’s also helpful to keep the context of these questions in mind. These people aren’t prying. As you said, they’re trained to make small talk so that customers feel comfortable. Depersonalizing the ask can help. When someone asks, “what are you doing for the rest of the day?” remind yourself that this is not actually a question designed for you. They’re talking to you, but they’re not actually talking to you, if that makes sense. It’s also fine to assert your internal boundary in a friendly but direct way. “Thanks for asking, but I’m not much of a chatter. I hope you’re having a good day, though.” Dear Eric: My closest friend of many years has recently revealed the sad news that she has terminal cancer. She is one of those rare humans that most people have an instant connection to, and then they become fast friends. In addition to being close friends, we were colleagues who often worked closely together, traveled together and shared many common friends, work friends, vendors and clients. Several decades worth of projects and likely in the hundreds of people within that group. There is a very small group (less than five people) of us who she has shared the news with. She has expressed her preference to not share details with our greater community until she can get her bearings with diagnosis and treatment, however, she will eventually want us to tell friends her story and status updates. Our small group is aligned on supporting her in any way and her wishes; she does not have a significant other or family to help her shoulder the burden. What are the words to inevitably use when I share the information to our work community knowing they’re more than just colleagues? How do I grieve with others as they learn her prognosis and safeguard my own emotional state as I share her story? I don’t know how to navigate this all without breaking down anytime I think about it or talk about her situation. – Grieving Best Friend Dear Best Friend: I’m sorry for what your friend is going through, and what you’re facing as well. This is hard. And it’s fine if you have the capacity to hold your friend through it but not enough left over to help others process. With regard to the words, you’re going to want to take your cue from your friend in terms of how much she wants shared. When she indicates she’s ready for the larger community to know, ask her about her boundaries, her wishes for communication and what places feel too exposed. Sometimes, something brief, compassionate, and direct can give people the information they need and guidance about how to respond. Here’s one potential: “I want to share some very hard news about our colleague and friend. She’s received a diagnosis of [diagnosis]. [Here you might add a sentence about her prognosis or how she’s doing, depending on your friend’s wishes.] As you can imagine, this is an overwhelming time. Instead of calls or emails, our friend is asking that any communication about updates go through [either list a designated updater or a health update site like CaringBridge.org]” Resist the urge to preemptively memorialize in this message; instead, you can share your grief, your fears and your memories with the small group and with others in your personal circle that you trust. To protect yourself, I encourage you to look into one of the update sites, rather than directing people to reach out to one of you about what’s going on. It’s in our nature as people to slide from questions to processing. These sites provide a buffer that will give you the needed space to safeguard your emotions. Others may want to know more or to offer sympathies, but the most important thing right now is that the people closest to your friend, you included, have the capacity to fully show up for your friend. Send questions to R. Eric Thomas at eric@askingeric.com or P.O. Box 22474, Philadelphia, PA 19110. Follow him on Instagram and sign up for his weekly newsletter at rericthomas.com. R. Eric Thomas (he/him) is a national bestselling author, playwright, and screenwriter. His memoir, Here for It, or How to Save Your Soul in America, which Lin-Manuel Miranda hailed as “pop culture-obsessed,... more If you purchase a product or register for an account through a link on our site, we may receive compensation. By using this site, you consent to our User Agreement and agree that your clicks, interactions, and personal information may be collected, recorded, and/or stored by us and social media and other third-party partners in accordance with our Privacy Policy.
summary: Many companies are training their employees to “be friendlier . I find that to be very intrusive from someone I don't know and may never see again . I understand they have been trained so it isn't necessarily their fault, but I need a better response .

title: Fact-check: Disturbing child abuse clip originated in Iraq, not Pakistan
text: The incident was reported by Iraqi media, which stated that the father had been arrested by the police Updated Saturday Nov 15 2025 Trigger Warning: Violence against a child The following fact check discusses a video containing distressing footage of a young child being physically assaulted. Reader discretion is advised. A viral video shows a man brutally beating a young child with a plastic hose. Social media users claim the incident occurred in Pakistan and have called on authorities to intervene. The claim is false. The video was not filmed in Pakistan. On November 4, a Facebook user shared a six-second video with a caption in Urdu reading: “Please share this clip as widely as possible so that this man is punished for what he did. Should a teacher behave like this?” The clip shows a man hitting a young girl, who is cornered and crying in pain. At the time of writing, the video had been viewed over 9,000 times on Facebook. The claims also took off on X (formerly known as Twitter), Facebook and Instagram here, here and here. The video is from Iraq, not Pakistan, and shows a father violently beating his daughter. Geo Fact Check conducted a reverse image search of key frames from the video and traced the earliest upload to an account that posted it on October 30, identifying the man as being from Baghdad, Iraq. The incident was also reported by Iraqi media outlets 964 Media and Hatha Alyoum English, both of which stated on October 30 that the father had been arrested by Rusafa police. The news articles can be read here and here. Verdict: The child-abuse video was not filmed in Pakistan. It originated in Baghdad, Iraq, where local authorities have arrested the father shown in the video. Follow us on @GeoFactCheck on X (Twitter) and @geo_factcheck on Instagram. If our readers detect any errors, we encourage them to contact us at [email protected]
summary: A viral video shows a man brutally beating a young child with a plastic hose . Social media users claim the incident occurred in Pakistan and have called on authorities to intervene . The video is from Iraq, not Pakistan, and shows a father violently beating his daughter . The incident was reported by Iraqi media, which stated that the father had been arrested by the police .

title: Public advised against touching red seaweed in Kuala Nerus
text: KUALA NERUS: The public is advised not to touch or handle clumps of red seaweed that have washed ashore on the beaches of Universiti Malaysia Terengganu (UMT). Head of the UMT Reference & Repository Centre (RRC-UMT), Associate Professor Dr Muhammad Hafiz Borkhanuddin, said the advice was issued because physical contact with the species, which belongs to the Ceramiales group, may cause itching among individuals with sensitive skin. He said the appearance of red seaweed is commonly observed ahead of the Northeast Monsoon (MTL) transition, when strong winds, coastal currents and powerful waves dislodge the species from the seabed and push it ashore. "Recently, we have observed a phenomenon of red seaweed washing up along the UMT beach. The seaweed is light red, thread-like with short segments, soft and not easily broken. "It is not toxic, but it is easily damaged when exposed to freshwater such as rain. The risk to humans relates mainly to physical contact on the beach or in the water, and individuals with sensitive skin may experience itching,” he said in a statement on Saturday (Nov 15). Muhammad Hafiz said seaweed has a wide global distribution, occurring in both temperate and tropical regions. He added that similar occurrences of seaweed washing ashore on the UMT coastline were recorded between August and December 2003, as well as in October 2016. "Seaweed clumps that are not collected will undergo natural degradation. The liquid produced during this process will accumulate beneath the clumps, emitting a foul odour and attracting large numbers of small insects. "The main risk is the release of toxic hydrogen sulfide gas, which can cause dizziness and nausea. Therefore, the public is advised to avoid any activities in areas where red seaweed has washed up,” he said. However, Muhammad Hafiz said that the phenomenon is not a sign of pollution, but rather a natural process within the coastal ecosystem, where seaweed serves as a temporary habitat for small marine organisms such as amphipods, isopods and coastal insects. — Bernama Thank you for your report!
summary: The public is advised not to touch or handle clumps of red seaweed that have washed ashore on the beaches of Universiti Malaysia Terengganu (UMT) Head of the UMT Reference & Repository Centre (RRC-UMT), Associate Professor Dr Muhammad Hafiz Borkhanuddin, said the advice was issued because physical contact with the species may cause itching among individuals with sensitive skin .

title: Tigers tear through Grizzlies in state semis
text: MOSCOW — Top seed and defending-champion Kendrick lived up to its billing and then some in Idaho Class 2A state football playoff semifinal action on Friday at the P1FCU Kibbie Dome. Facing south Idaho’s top 2A team, the fourth-seeded Grace Grizzlies, the undefeated Tigers produced a rout of proportions seldom seen in the latter stages of the postseason to prevail 82-6. “They played lights out,” Kendrick coach Ty Koepp said of his Tigers. “They worked really hard all week, had our best week in practice going into this. I’m just proud of the boys; now it’s on to the next week and getting ready.” Kendrick’s starters scored on every one of their possessions and three of Grace’s (a safety and two interception returns) en route to building a 76-0 lead before heading to the bench midway through the third quarter. The Grizzlies proved evenly matched with the Tigers’ second-stringers from there on out. Kendrick’s last remaining obstacle to a fifth consecutive state title (and second straight since moving up to Class 2A) now lies in the third-seeded Logos Knights of Moscow, who avenged themselves in style on the second-seeded Kamiah Kubs in the day’s other semifinal. The Tigers and Knights will return to the Kibbie Dome for a title game on Friday of next week. Resistance is futile There was a sense for much of the first quarter that Grace (9-2), which had finished the regular season ranked second in Idaho Class 2A state media polling and received its fourth seed based on MaxPreps computer rankings, might be able to offer some resistance. The Tigers (11-0) quickly whisked the ball down the field and scored each time they had possession, but the Grizzlies proved stubborn and reliable enough to manage a series of prolonged drives inching their way forward with apparent hope of scoring. Grace’s second drive, with Kendrick leading 16-0 late in the first quarter, came all the way to the brink of the Tigers’ end zone, but a pair of tackles by defensive back Cade Silflow and a sack by lineman Travis Hix thwarted their ambitions and led to a turnover on downs. Kendrick’s Tanner Clemenhagen then promptly blazed to a 65-yard rushing touchdown, weaving between Grace defenders to establish a 22-0 lead that reinforced the sense that the rout was on. The floodgates were wide open in the second quarter, which began with Kendrick’s junior lineman Keegan Anderson inflicting a safety on Grace — an accurate signal that the Grizzlies’ glimmers of offensive success had faded. The score swelled to 56-0 by halftime, and the Tiger starters reeled off another 20 points over the first few minutes of the third quarter for good measure before the second string took over. Grace finally got on the board with just under a minute remaining in the third quarter, while Kendrick’s relief quarterback Hank Heimgartner connected with Hudson Kirkland for a fourth-quarter 73-yard passing play to log the final points of the evening. Stats of note Kendrick quarterback Maddox Kirkland had a customarily dominant night, following up on an opening-drive rushing touchdown with a 9-for-14 passing performance for 276 yards and four more TDs. “I just had to get the ball out to my players, and they made plays happen and made me look good,” Kirkland said. Cade Silflow was Kirkland’s most prolific receiver, catching five passes for 160 yards and three touchdowns. On the ground, Ralli Roetcisoender was highly efficient, using three rushes to amass 49 yards and two touchdowns before adding an interception-return score to boot. Fans in force The always-lively Kendrick fan community turned out in force for this game. Thomas Duggan, one of a group of young boys who sat at the front of the stands passing around and waving an enlarged cardboard cutout of wide receiver Nathan Tweit’s head, could be heard shouting “Yeah Nathan!” as Tweit caught a midfield pass from Kirkland and tore to the end zone for an early second-quarter touchdown. Paul Hutcheson, a 67-year-old lifelong Kendrick resident and longtime visible presence at Tiger sporting events, continued a personal tradition when he stood up at the end of the third quarter to lead a chant of “Give me a T! Give me an I” and so forth. Looking ahead Logos (9-2) is the only team to have bested Kendrick in the last four years, inflicting a 30-18 regular-season league defeat on the Tigers last year before Kendrick struck back in a 52-26 state semifinal. A 48-24 league victory against the Knights was by far the Tigers’ most competitive game so far this season, in which they trailed 16-14 at halftime and nosed ahead 20-16 through three quarters before an offensive explosion in the fourth turned it into a runaway. “They’re a great football team,” Koepp said of Logos. “They work really hard as well; they’re very well coached; so it’ll be a great game.” Grace 0 0 6 0— 6 Kendrick 22 34 20 6—82 FIRST QUARTER Kendrick — Maddox Kirkland 1 run (Ralli Roetcisoender run). Kendrick — Roetcisoender 18 run (Cade Silflow pass from Kirkland). Kendrick — Tanner Clemenhagen 65 run (run failed). SECOND QUARTER Kendrick — Safety. Kendrick — Roetcisoender 7 run (Orion Stewart run). Kendrick — Nathan Tweit 55 pass from Kirkland (run failed). Kendrick — Roetcisoender 45 interception return (run failed). Kendrick — Silflow 39 pass from Kirkland (run failed). Kendrick — Orion Stewart 5 run (pass failed). THIRD QUARTER Kendrick — Silflow 39 pass from Kirkland (Silflow pass from Kirkland). Kendrick — Silflow 35 pass from Kirkland (pass failed). Kendrick — Landon Sneve 20 interception return (run failed). Grace — Tate Stoddard 38 run (kick failed). FOURTH QUARTER Kendrick — Hank Heimgartner 73 pass to Hudson Kirkland (run failed). Wendt may be contacted at (208) 848-2268, or cwendt@lmtribune.com.
summary: Kendrick wins 82-6 over fourth-seeded Grace Grizzlies in Idaho Class 2A state football playoff semifinal . Top seed Kendrick, the defending champion Kendrick, scores on every one of its possessions and three of Grace’s (a safety and two interception returns) The Tigers and the Logos Knights will return to the Kibbie Dome for a title game on Friday of next week .

title: Former Buckingham Palace worker reveals one person that can say 'no' to King Charles
text: Former Royal butler Paul Burrell has revealed there is only one person who can refuse King Charles as he offered his insights on the current Royal Family dynamics. In his book The Royal Insider: My Life with the Queen, the King and Princess Diana, Paul, 67, identified the sole individual capable of declining the monarch as his spouse of two decades, Queen Camilla. Paul characterized the Queen as a "non-negotiable" figure who seldom requests much, yet receives everything. He stated: "Charles has always lived in a world where all his household and staff bow and call him 'your Royal Highness'. Now, of course, it is 'Your Majesty'. Nobody says no. If you do, you're out.", reports The Mirror. "He lives in a gilded bubble and is served whatever he wants, whenever he wants and by whom he wants. The only person that can say 'no' is Camilla. She is and always will be a non-negotiable. Perhaps her no-nonsense approach is what Charles needs. "She's the steady hand on the tiller of the royal ship now, like it or not. She is at the helm. She rarely asks for anything but is given everything and now has the ultimate position as queen." Beyond identifying the singular person who can deny the 76 year old monarch, Paul also asserted that Charles' daily routines have remained largely unchanged through the years. He penned: "His routines have never changed. His toothpaste is squeezed onto his toothbrush every morning and he uses a silver key which winds down the tube to avoid any waste. "His pyjamas are laundered or pressed every day, the drawstring tapes pressed flat like his shoelaces. He, again like his father, likes his dress shoes to be 'spit-and-polished' to a mirror finish." While Paul remarked on Charles' longstanding daily rituals, another former butler weighed in on how the King might have reacted to a military-themed social media post shared by Prince Harry's wife, Meghan Markle, earlier this week. Meghan posted the video to honor Veterans Day, America's version of Remembrance Day, celebrating the contributions of her husband and all military personnel. Regarding what Charles may have made of the post, former Royal butler Grant Harrold told ReachPlc that he suspects the King would have embraced it. You agree you are 18 or over. We use your sign-up to provide content in ways you’ve consented to and improve our understanding of you. This may include adverts from us and third parties based on our knowledge of you. Unsubscribe at any time. More info. He stated: "It's a very powerful video, and a very emotive post. It's definitely showing Meghan's move to a more 'celebrity' approach to social media, sharing the video she wants and feels are important on key days. "It's a really nice post. I don't think the Royal Family will feel badly about it at all; I think they will approve it. "She's marking Veterans Day-which is America's version of Remembrance Day-and showing her pride in the active service her husband undertook. "The King was extremely proud of his son serving in Afghanistan, and he will be glad at Meghan acknowledging and respecting this."
summary: Former Royal butler Paul Burrell has revealed there is only one person who can refuse King Charles . Paul characterized the Queen as a "non-negotiable" figure who seldom requests much, yet receives everything . Paul also noted that Charles' daily routines have remained largely unchanged through the years .

title: Maithili Thakur’s Indian Idol Video Goes Viral After Her Alinagar MLA Victory — Watch
text: Maithili Thakur’s old Indian Idol video has gone viral again following her victory as the new Alinagar MLA. Fans are revisiting her musical journey, celebrating how the former teenage singer has now risen to become one of Bihar’s youngest legislators. Trending Photos Maithili Thakur, the 25-year-old singer who first rose to fame through TV music shows, is now making a strong mark in Bihar’s political landscape. Contesting from the Alinagar seat, she has taken a significant lead of 84,915 votes over RJD candidate Binod Mishra, positioning herself for a landmark victory. Maithili is poised to become the youngest MLA in the Bihar Assembly. Her rise is remarkable—transitioning from a popular teenage performer to a prominent BJP figure in a constituency where the party has never won before. She turned 25 in July, and her entry into an assembly where the average candidate age is around 51 highlights the generational shift she represents. The last time Bihar saw such a young winner was in 2005, when independent candidate Tauseef Alam was elected at 26, followed later by RJD’s Tejashwi Yadav, also at 26. Maithili’s popularity is not new. Her old Indian Idol audition video recently went viral again, reminding the internet of her powerful voice and humble beginnings on national television. This resurgence of her musical clips further boosted interest in her political journey, drawing attention to how far she has come since her teenage years. Add Zee News as a Preferred Source Without debating about her Qualification, her choice, pros n cons... Today, She Contested Bihar Assembly Elections. She is the BJP Candidate from Alinagar Seat. #MaithiliThakur pic.twitter.com/9ouaBwba1k (@Polytikles) November 14, 2025 Her election campaign stood out for its strong family involvement. Her younger brothers—Rishav, a tabla player, and Ayachi, the youngest—accompanied her throughout the campaign, performing folk music at rallies to emphasise her cultural roots. Their presence helped reinforce her identity in Mithila, a region known for its artistic heritage. Supporting them were her maternal uncles, Nand Kishore Jha and Sumit Jha, who handled coordination and ground operations across Alinagar. The Thakur siblings have long been social-media favourites, especially for their soulful performances featuring Ramcharitmanas recitations, which have garnered millions of views online. Over the years, Maithili has been recognised with several honours, including the Atal Mithila Samman and the Lokmat Sur Jyotsna National Music Award. In 2019, she and her brothers were appointed brand ambassadors for Madhubani by the Election Commission. Her shift from cultural icon to political newcomer reflects a strategic move by the BJP to expand its appeal in regions traditionally seen as difficult terrain. Should the counting end in her favour, Maithili Thakur’s victory will stand out as one of the most compelling narratives of this Bihar election—an artist gracefully stepping into politics while carrying forward both tradition and ambition. title: Lahore HC judge Shams Mahmood Mirza joins resignations wave
text: Lahore: Following Supreme Court’s senior judges, Justice Shams Mahmood Mirza of Lahore High Court has resigned. He submitted his resignation to the President of Pakistan. Justice Mirza left his chambers quietly, without formal protocol. Justice Shams Mahmood Mirza took oath as an additional judge of Lahore High Court on March 22, 2014. He was scheduled to retire in 2028. He is the son of former Supreme Court judge Zia Mahmood Mirza. Read more: Two Supreme Court judges resign over 27th constitutional amendment The resignation comes after the 27th Constitutional Amendment, which also prompted resignations from Supreme Court judges Justice Mansoor Ali Shah and Justice Athar Minallah. Their resignations were accepted by the President. Justice Mirza was also a member of the Lahore High Court’s administrative committee. Justice Mansoor Ali Shah had stated in his resignation that the amendment undermined judicial independence. He described it as a serious attack on Pakistan’s constitutional democracy. He said remaining in office would mean silent consent to unconstitutional changes. Read more: Kh Asif assails SC judges for stepping down Justice Athar Minallah similarly said the oath he took to protect the Constitution no longer holds. He explained that despite trying to convince himself otherwise, he could no longer serve under the new framework. Both resignations signal deep concerns over judicial autonomy and governance.
source: Daily Times - Latest Pakistan News, World, Busines
summary: Justice Shams Mahmood Mirza of Lahore High Court has resigned . He submitted his resignation to the President of Pakistan . The resignation comes after the 27th Constitutional Amendment . Supreme Court judges Mansoor Ali Shah and Athar Minallah also resigned .

title: Lotto Powerball: Three winners split record-breaking jackpot, get $18.3m each
text: Three players have split tonight’s $55 million Lotto jackpot, winning $18.3m each. The numbers in the must-be-won draw were: 38, 28, 2, 5, 14, 19. The bonus was: 29 and Powerball was 6. Lotto won’t release the location of the winners until tomorrow morning. “What a fantastic result. It’s great to see the Powerball jackpot being shared among a number of players,” said Lotto NZ chief executive Jason Delamore. “A win like this doesn’t just change one life – it can transform families, friends, and even entire communities. Our winners often give back in incredible ways, from helping loved ones to supporting charities." “The impact of this win will reach far beyond the individual winners,” he said. Fifteen other lucky Lotto punters will also be celebrating after winning a $55,556 share of Lotto First Division. Sixty-two other players also won $16,909 in Lotto Second Division. Of Aotearoa’s 12 previous “must-be-won” draws, the top prize has been shared at a lower division seven times. Victoria University of Wellington’s Richard Arnold said there was about a 30% chance the full $55m would be won by one person, depending on the total number of players. He told Herald NOW’s Ryan Bridge if two million players buy 10 lines each, there’s about a 30% chance of a single winner in Division 1. He said if there are four million players, that probably goes up to about 36%. The winners of the last $50m jackpot told Lotto NZ the key was not to be changed by the sudden wealth. They advised tonight’s winners to “make sure you’re confident in the team you build around you – you have to trust they are giving you good advice". Ticket holders can see immediately if they have won if they purchased a ticket through MyLotto. Prizes of $1000 or less are automatically credited to the account. For prizes exceeding $1000, winners must complete an online prize claim form. Winners with a physical ticket must still visit a Lotto retailer to claim their prize. For the Powerball jackpot to be claimed, a ticket holder must get all six Lotto numbers correct as well as the added Powerball number. Sign up to The Daily H, a free newsletter curated by our editors and delivered straight to your inbox every weekday.
summary: The numbers in the must-be-won draw were: 38, 28, 2, 5, 14, 19 and Powerball was 6 . Lotto won't release the location of the winners until tomorrow morning . Fifteen other lucky Lotto punters will also be celebrating after winning a $55,556 share of Lotto First Division . Sixty-two other players also won $16,909 in Lotto Second Division .

title: Positive trends show tariff reforms, FBR modernization bearing fruits: PM
text: ISLAMABAD: Prime Minister Muhammad Shehbaz Sharif Saturday said that the positive trends due to tariff reforms and the government’s steps to modernize and improve the Federal Board of Revenue (FBR) transparently were solid evidence of the correctness of the measures. He was chairing the weekly review meeting on reforms in the country’s tax system. “The latest economic statistics are proving the government’s economic reforms are working, as a result of which the pace of economic growth is improving every day, evidence of which is also coming before the business community and the nation,” he added. During the meeting, it was briefed that the tariff reforms carried out this year have not had any negative impact on revenue collection, rather, the collection of duties and taxes at the import level has increased by 25 percent. وزیراعظم محمد شہباز شریف کی زیر صدارت ملکی ٹیکس نظام میں اصلاحات پر ہفتہ وار جائزہ اجلاس وزیراعظم نے ٹیکس چوری روکنے، تمباکو، ٹائلز اور دیگر بڑے شعبوں میں ٹیکس وصولی کے نظام میں موجود خامیوں کو مرحلہ وار موثر انداز میں ختم کرنے کے لیے انتظامی اور اداراجاتی اقدامات اٹھانے کی… pic.twitter.com/KlHEg02ANw — Government of Pakistan (@GovtofPakistan) November 15, 2025 This increase came despite a mere 3.6% increase in the volume of dutiable products, which also disproved fears that reducing tariffs would reduce revenue collection. The participants were told that duty-free imports increased by 41.5%, which means that a large increase in imports has occurred in products that fall under the category of raw materials and intermediate goods. This can be considered a sign of significant improvement in the impact on productivity at the basic level. The meeting was told that the ongoing economic reforms, including tariff reduction and improvement of the tax system were aimed at increasing manufacturing and exports, thereby making the environment more conducive for investment in the country. Islamabad: Prime Minister Muhammad Shehbaz Sharif chairs weekly progress review meeting on FBR reforms. pic.twitter.com/a3L0NLdjs5 — Government of Pakistan (@GovtofPakistan) November 15, 2025 The increase in imports of goods falling under the category of duty-free imports is a sign of the effectiveness of the government’s tariff rationalization measures, which are aimed at increasing the import of raw materials and secondary goods. It was informed that the aim of tariff reforms was to reduce the cost of raw materials used in the manufacturing sector so that the volume of domestic exports could increase and competitiveness in the global market could be achieved. Latest data proves that this policy of the government has been successful. The results achieved from customs reforms also include the effects of the successful government strategy of making the FBR a modern, transparent and viable institution. The prime minister directed to take administrative and institutional measures to prevent tax evasion and eliminate the shortcomings in the tax collection system in tobacco, tiles and other major sectors in a phased and effective manner. He congratulated the entire finance team including the FBR and stressed that the pace of effective implementation of the reform process should be further accelerated so that Pakistan can get out of the vortex of economic difficulties and be able to truly meet the sustainable development goals. Federal Minister for Finance Muhammad Aurangzeb, Federal Minister for Climate Change Dr. Musadik Malik, Federal Minister for Petroleum Ali Pervaiz Malik, Minister of State for Finance Azhar Bilal Kayani, chief secretaries of all provinces, Chairman FBR and other relevant government officials attended the meeting. PM felicitates Green Shirts on winning ODI series against Sri Lanka Prime Minister Muhammad Shehbaz Sharif, Saturday, congratulated the national cricket team on winning the tri-One Day International (ODI) series against the visiting Sri Lankan team. On his X handle, the prime minister posted, “I congratulate our national team on winning the ODI series against Sri Lanka, and I commend Chairman PCB Mohsin Naqvi and his entire team for their great efforts.” It was a wonderful display of cricket’s unifying spirit, he further said, expressing special thanks to the Sri Lankan players and management. Their participation once again reflected the enduring friendship between the two nations. Pakistan leads the three ODI series by 2-0. summary: Prime Minister Muhammad Shehbaz Sharif chairing weekly review meeting on reforms in the country’s tax system . Tariff reforms carried out this year have not had any negative impact on revenue collection, rather, the collection of duties and taxes at the import level has increased by 25 percent .

title: USC football vs Iowa -- live updates, analysis for Week 12 showdown
text: The USC Trojans faced the Iowa Hawkeyes, trying to keep their College Football Playoff hopes alive. USC was focused on staying alive for another week and making next week's trip to Oregon matter. USC desperately wanted to fly to Eugene and make sure it faced the Ducks for high stakes. Mission accomplished. It would have been a huge letdown for USC football and Lincoln Riley to travel to the Pacific Northwest with all their dreams dashed and nothing to play for other than pride. By beating Iowa, USC managed to make that game a main event. It marks a positive progression from last season, when the Trojans were playing out the string at this time. USC playing for something big in late November -- even if it doesn't achieve what it ultimately wants -- represents a forward-moving development for the football program going into 2026. Here's how USC's second-half comeback against Iowa unfolded in a wet LA Coliseum: Wow! This team, so soft and so substandard in the first half, showed an enormous amount of guts and toughness in the second half. USC outscored Iowa 19-0 after falling behind 21-7, and shut out the Hawkeyes in the second half. The defense still needs a lot of work, but the team grew in a moment of crisis instead of shriveling. Now the Oregon game matters. Now Lincoln Riley can credibly say his team is learning how to win. There's a lot to discuss, and we will certainly keep the conversation going over the weekend here. Lincoln Riley throws the ball on second down, going for the win instead of just trying to drain Iowa's timeouts. Jayden Maiava throws a strike and this one is just about over. Iowa had a man open on 4th and 6 but he couldn't get his foot down in the USC red zone. The Trojans take over and are close to getting this thing done. Iowa and Gronowski continue to miss throws. USC continues to get stops. Now the Trojans get the ball back with a chance to put this game away. The Trojans lead with just over 13 minutes left. USC has been a great second-half team in recent weeks after playing below-average first halves. Now the Trojans have to finish the job. Will Iowa be able to run the ball despite trailing? That seems to be the big key in the final quarter. The Trojans are inside the Iowa 10 as the quarter ends. This game has undergone a complete 180. Makai Lemon is the difference, but Iowa's passing game has also made crucial errors to hand-deliver the Trojans a golden opportunity to steal this game. Mark Gronowski is not a good passer, but you wouldn't have known it from the way he carved up USC early on. Now, however, his limitations are showing up. He missed an easy throw on Iowa's latest possession and then waited far too long to hit a receiver. The ball was deflected and picked off. USC is on the verge of taking the lead with the ball near the Iowa 40. The 2-point try fails, but USC is definitely back in the game after an 82-yard touchdown drive with Makai Lemon dominating. He's making high-level catches and is in God mode right now. This is the best we've seen from Lemon all season. This is what a Biletnikoff Award winner looks like. It's pretty simple: Keep Iowa out of the end zone, win the game. Iowa probably isn't winning this game with only 24 points. A good drive bogs down because of a penalty. The Trojans settle for three and now have to play some defense to really get back in this game. This is just a poorly-coached team which keeps doing the same bad things without course corrections or improvements. It's not the USC standard. If this team doesn't rally in 30 minutes, the season is essentially over. Stop if you've heard this before: A big USC play is wiped out by an illegal man downfield penalty on a lineman. It's the third time that has happened this season. The Trojan defense is soft and is getting dragged around the Coliseum. This is just a horror show. I thought Halloween was over. A brilliant drive from Jayden Maiava. He converts a short-yardage situation with a keeper -- the kind of play USC fans have been clamoring for -- and then eludes a pass rusher to make a downfield throw near the sideline to set up a touchdown. USC needed 20 minutes to wake up, but at least the Trojans are here. They're back in it. Just completely unacceptable on every level. The Hawkeyes are about to make it 14-0. USC is getting punched in the mouth. What was this coaching staff doing all week? USC hasn't shown any indication that it was prepared for Iowa. USC goes for it on 4th and 1 near midfield. The play gets blown up. It wasn't even close. Iowa far more physical in the first quarter, much like Nebraska. This is pathetic. USC failed to cover a simple out route on 3rd and 8, but Iowa quarterback Mark Gronowski badly misfired, forcing the Hawkeyes to punt. USC is asleep at the wheel and is lucky to be down only seven. Ja'Kobi Lane drops a pass which would have produced a first down. USC is back to its bad habits again. This team cannot manage to start a game playing well. It is rare these days. Michigan was the exception, not the rule. USC didn't cover anyone. It didn't get a pass rush. It allowed a bunch of big pass plays to Iowa. Other than that, great start. This article originally appeared on Trojans Wire: USC football storms back to beat Iowa in rain - recap, analysis
summary: USC outscored 19-0 after falling behind 21-7, and shut out the Hawkeyes in the second half . It marks a positive progression from last season, when the Trojans were playing out the string at this time . Now Lincoln Riley can credibly say his team is learning how to win .

title: Iran Confirms Seizure Of Tanker In Gulf
text: A South Korean-flagged tanker vessel which was seized by Iran. is seen in Gulf, Iran January 4, 2021. IRGC / WANA (West Asia News Agency) via REUTERS DUBAI, Nov 15 (Reuters) – Iran confirmed on Saturday that its Revolutionary Guards had seized a tanker in Gulf waters carrying a cargo of petrochemicals bound for Singapore over alleged violations, Iranian state media reported. A U.S. official and maritime security sources had said on Friday that Iranian forces intercepted the oil products tanker and diverted it into Iranian territorial waters. It was the first report of Tehran seizing a tanker since Israeli-U.S. strikes on Iran in June. Iranian state-run television read a statement from the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) stating that “the tanker was in violation for carrying unauthorized cargo.” It did not provide further details of the alleged violations. The Marshall Islands-flagged tanker, the Talara, had been sailing off the United Arab Emirates’ coast, maritime sources said, and was carrying a cargo of high-sulfur gasoil through the Indian Ocean en route to Singapore from Sharjah in the UAE. The vessel’s manager Columbia Shipmanagement said it lost contact with the Talara Friday morning around 20 nautical miles off the coast of Khor Fakkan, UAE. It added that it was working closely with relevant parties, including maritime security agencies and the vessel’s owner, to restore contact. The ship is owned by Cyprus-based Pasha Finance. In a statement, the U.S. military said it was aware of the incident and was actively monitoring the situation. Iran’s IRGC has periodically seized commercial vessels in Gulf waters in recent years, often citing maritime violations such as alleged smuggling, technical infractions or legal disputes. However, the U.S. official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the incident was surprising since Iran had not carried out any such operations in recent months. Iran has curbed its military activities in the region since the 12-day Israeli bombing campaign in June, which was joined by the United States. Its last reported seizure of a vessel was in April 2024. (Editing by Louise Heavens and Joe Bavier) (c) Copyright Thomson Reuters 2025. Sign up for gCaptain’s newsletter and never miss an update
summary: Iran confirms it has seized a tanker in Gulf waters carrying a cargo of petrochemicals bound for Singapore . U.S. official and maritime security sources had said on Friday that Iranian forces intercepted the oil products tanker and diverted it into Iranian territorial waters . Iranian state-run television read a statement from the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) stating that “the tanker was in violation for carrying unauthorized cargo”

title: Woman charged in shooting that killed innocent bystander
text: Now 68° Sun 85° Mon 85° by Steven Pappas & WHAM Staff Rochester, N.Y. (WHAM) — A suspect is in custody in connection to a deadly shooting earlier this month on the city's west side. Kitana Kendrick, 30, was struck by a stray bullet during a fight on Gothic Street Nov. 2, according to Rochester police, who said Kendrick was an innocent bystander and was not the intended target. She was rushed to Strong Memorial Hospital and died a short time after arriving. Nobody else was hurt. BACKGROUND: Family of woman killed by stray round left with 'more questions than answers' | Woman, 30, shot and killed on Gothic Street was hit by stray round, Rochester police say Aryana Stone, 24, of Rochester was arrested Friday by members of the United States Marshal's Service in the Buffalo area and charged with second-degree murder for Kendrick's killing, police said. "My niece doesn't get to walk the streets anymore, so neither should this person," Adrian Arguinzoni, Kendrick's aunt, said during an interview Friday after the arrest was announced. "She needs to face the consequences for what she did." Stone had an outstanding warrant for violating her probation stemming from previous charges of attempted robbery and attempted assault, police said. "Unfortunately, when you make decisions that affect other people, we want to have the dignity to be here, be present, and express what we as a family are feeling right now," said Eveliss Cuebas, Kendrick's cousin. Stone was arraigned on murder in the second degree and criminal possession of a weapon charges in Rochester City Court, according to Calli Marianetti, the community relations director for the Monroe County District Attorney's Office. The investigation remains ongoing. Anyone with information is asked to call 911, Crime Stoppers at (585) 423-9300, RPD's Major Crimes Unit at (585) 428-7157 or email MajorCrimes@cityofrochester.gov.
summary: Kitana Kendrick, 30, was struck by a stray bullet during a fight on Gothic Street Nov. 2 . She was rushed to Strong Memorial Hospital and died a short time after arriving . Aryana Stone, 24, of Rochester was arrested Friday by members of the United States Marshal's Service in Buffalo area .

title: Federal judge finds ICE's license plate checks led to unlawful arrest in Beaverton case
text: Now 68° Sun 85° Mon 85° by Jennifer Singh A view of the Federal Courthouse after a protest on March 11, 2021 (KATU Photo) PORTLAND, Ore. (KATU) — A federal judge has ruled the recent detainment of a 24-year-old Guatemalan man in Beaverton unlawful after ICE randomly ran drivers’ plates to check their immigration status. According to court documents, on November 8, ICE officers ran the license plate of the defendant, named as J.Y.L.C., and he was pulled over due to the vehicle registration having a different address than ICE had on file. Respondents of the case said at the time, they were “randomly running the license plates of vehicles traveling around them and the names and dates of birth of the registered wonders of those vehicles through DHS systems to determine if the registered owner was in the United States unlawfully.” RELATED: Congressional push to sever ICE's DMV data access gains traction in Democratic-led states They went on to say “[v]ehicles were chosen at random and were not targeted based on any characteristics of the driver or the vehicle.” Court documents show the officers generated a warrant on the spot for the defendant’s arrest before pulling him over, saying failure to update his address “rendered him a flight risk.” Additionally, according to his lawyer, Nicholas Costa, federal agents told J.Y.L.C. he had a deportation order as well. J.Y.L.C. also admitted to driving without a license. He was arrested immediately and was ultimately transported to the ICE facility in Tacoma. Court documents show ICE detained the man under Section 235(b)(2)(A) of the Immigration and Nationality Act, which requires immediate detention for incoming immigrants until they can be formally removed. However, U.S. District Judge Amy Baggio determined that law does not apply to the defendant, who has been living in Oregon for eight years. Costa, tells KATU that J.Y.L.C is under “legal presence” in Oregon. According to Costa, he entered the United States in 2017 when he was 16 years old and has lived in Oregon since then. Documents also show he filed for asylum in 2019, with a hearing set for next month. Costa also said his client lives in Beaverton, works a full-time job in construction, and is the sole caregiver for his partner and his 13-month old child. "He's got a social security number, he files his taxes, pays his bills, takes care of his kids," Costa said. "So, he's doing everything right." Costa said when he received the call that his client was detained, he immediately filed a habeas petition and a temporary restraining order in federal district court. "To get this thing filed, we had nine minutes before they transferred my client from Oregon to Washington where the detention facility is, and had I not filed that within that small window of time, the judge wouldn't have had jurisdiction and wouldn't have been able to file the orders that she did," Costa said. According to Costa, J.Y.L.C. had moved just around the corner from his original address, but had forgotten to update records, the reason for the address discrepancy. "He had no reason to lie," Costa said. " He truly believed that he had done nothing wrong. In fact, it was a little outrageous that the ICE attorney claimed that he had a removal order, and that was actually presented in the evidence that I submitted yesterday." Judge Baggio told ICE that J.Y.L.C. must receive a bond hearing by Friday (November 14) or he is to be released. Costa said that bond hearing did happen on Friday, and a bail was set, but not after the facility closed its business hours, meaning the family cannot pay bond until the facility opens back up Monday morning. "That bond order came after ICE was closed at 3 p.m., and so the family was not able to pay the bond, and so my client is still detained in Tacoma until Monday when the ICE office is opened at 9 a.m.," Costa said. "Now, granted, they're still operating everywhere in Oregon and Beaverton, arresting people over the weekend, so it defies logic that they're not open to receive a bond from my client to release him." Once J.Y.L.C. is released on bail, a hearing will take place in Portland in December. Updates to this story are expected
summary: A federal judge ruled the detainment of a 24-year-old Guatemalan man in Oregon unlawful after ICE randomly ran drivers’ plates to check their immigration status . ICE officers ran the license plate of the defendant, named as J.Y.L.C., and he was pulled over due to the vehicle registration having a different address than ICE had on file . The defendant has been living in Oregon for eight years, his lawyer says .

title: Man dies after crashing car into body of water in Hillsdale County
text: HILLSDALE COUNTY, MI – A Jonesville man died Friday morning after crashing his car into a body of water. Dakota Wesley Osborne died Friday, Nov. 14, at the hospital not long after being pulled from the water and taken for emergency treatment, according to the Hillsdale County Sheriff’s Office. Nathan Clark is an MLive reporter for The Jackson Citizen Patriot and The Ann Arbor News. He previously did reporting work for The Flint Journal. title: Wallace shines, but Illinois offense stalls in road loss to Oregon State
text: CORVALLIS, OR. — A tough one on the road. The Illini traveled west for their first game away from Champaign of the season, taking on the Oregon State Beavers Friday night. The road game proved to be too big a challenge for the Illini, with the team coming up just short 64-59. The opening quarter set the tone with fast starts followed by cold spells. Oregon State came out firing from deep, hitting its first two threes, while Illinois answered with back-to-back midrange makes. After that early exchange, neither team could buy a basket. The Beavers went over two minutes without a field goal and turned it over three straight possessions. The second quarter swung completely in the Illini’s favor early. A steal and transition layup from Gretchen Dolan pushed the lead to 22-16, and Illinois looked ready to take control. However, the Beavers’ bench flipped the momentum. Their energy sparked an 11-0 run, holding Illinois scoreless for over five and a half minutes. Only two free throws from freshman guard Destiny Jackson finally broke the drought, and Illinois went into halftime trailing 29-28 after seeing a once six-point lead quickly disappear. Coming out of the break, Illinois found exactly one answer: Berry Wallace. The sophomore forward dominated the third quarter, scoring all but 3 of the Illini’s 14 points in the frame and almost single-handedly keeping Illinois in the game. She opened the half with six straight points, briefly putting Illinois ahead 34-31. Still, offensive help was scarce. Outside of Wallace, no Illini player scored until the final two minutes of the quarter, when Cearah Parchment hit a clutch three to tie the game at 41. Even with Wallace’s heroics, Illinois found itself down 43-41 entering the fourth. Wallace had 14 points and 3 rebounds through three quarters, while senior guard Tiara Bolden continued to rise for the Beavers with 13 points and 5 rebounds. The fourth quarter turned into a trading of big-time shots. Parchment drilled another one of her season-high 4 three-pointers with under two minutes left to cut the Beavers’ lead to three, setting up a tense finish. Yet again, however, Bolden answered. Her step-back three with 45 seconds remaining stretched the Beaver lead to eight and effectively sealed the game. She would finish with 25 points, tying her career high. Wallace kept Illinois alive with a banked-in three in the final seconds, bringing her total to 24 points, but it wasn’t enough. Oregon State closed it out at the line, handing Illinois its first loss of the season, 64-59. Road losses in November rarely define a season, and Illinois showed stretches of strong defense and individual brilliance that can still leave the fans with hope of a win next time out. Parchment gives the Illini an early lead with a rare 3 Wallace comes out of halftime on a tear, hitting a 3, followed by an and-1 layup to score the first 5 for Illinois. Wallace’s multiple and-1’s kept the Illini in the game for a while, but it still wasn’t enough. Illinois shot 42% from the beyond 3-point line. Illinois had 14 offensive rebounds. Oregon State scored 34 points in the paint. Illinois looks to bounce back when they are back home to host Murray State at State Farm Center. Tip-off is scheduled for 11 a.m. Tuesday and will stream on B1G+.
summary: The Illini lost 64-59 to the Oregon State Beavers on Friday night . The game was the team's first road game away from Champaign . Berry Wallace scored 14 points and 3 rebounds in the third quarter .

title: Pakistan and Jordan reject any displacement of Palestinians from Gaza
text: Jordan’s King Abdullah and Pakistan’s Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif have reaffirmed their “zero-tolerance” stance on any attempt to push Palestinians out of Gaza, doubling down on a position both leaders say is non-negotiable. Sharif hosted the Jordanian monarch in Islamabad for a two-day state visit, where the Gaza crisis dominated their talks. In a statement, Sharif’s office said, “On the issue of Palestine, both leaders acknowledged the unanimity of views and principled positions taken by Pakistan and Jordan regarding the post-war Gaza; zero-tolerance for any displacement of Palestinians from Gaza.” The two leaders also agreed to step up coordination among the eight Arab-Islamic states engaged in discussions with the United States over a possible ceasefire plan, a framework that includes proposals for a new governing arrangement in Gaza and the reconstruction of the enclave, which Israel has largely destroyed through months of bombardment.
summary: Jordan's King Abdullah and Pakistan's Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif have reaffirmed their “zero-tolerance” stance on any attempt to push Palestinians out of Gaza . The two leaders also agreed to step up coordination among Arab-Islamic states engaged in discussions with the United States over a possible ceasefire plan .

title: DuPont hangs up his waders
text: Joe DuPont didn’t know jobs like his existed when he was an undergraduate at the University of Idaho. He aspired to be a medical doctor or veterinarian. “I had no intentions of being a biologist. I don’t think I knew what one was,” he said. “I thought Fish and Game was game wardens.” On a whim, he applied for a Fish and Game gig at a UI job fair and promptly forgot about it. A few weeks later, he was offered and accepted a job running creel surveys in the Sawtooth Valley. “Over a span of three years, I recognized that I didn’t have a lot of empathy for cats or yappy dogs, so (being a vet) probably wasn’t in my future. If I was going to be a doctor, I wanted to be a surgeon and started thinking, ‘Man, that is a lot of years from now but I’m really liking what I’m doing now.’ ” He headed back to UI for graduate school and later took jobs with Avista and the Idaho Department of Lands before returning to Fish and Game. In 2008, he became the fisheries manager for the Clearwater Region and later this month will retire after 18 years guiding some of the state’s most popular and diverse fisheries. The region is renowned for its salmon and steelhead fishing. The Hells Canyon stretch of the Snake River is home to massive white sturgeon, one of the most iconic species in the Columbia River Basin. Tributaries to the Clearwater River that pour out of the Bitterroot Mountains provide blue ribbon westslope cutthroat trout fishing. Dworshak Reservoir boasts kokanee and record-challenging smallmouth bass, and the region has a series of small lakes, ponds and reservoirs cherished for trout, bass, bluegills and more. DuPont, who grew up near Moscow, had fished for many of those species as a kid and college student. “I never really had any intentions to come back and manage the same water I fished as a kid,” he said. “But it’s cool to be able to think about, ‘Oh yeah, I was doing this as a kid and think about how things have changed.’ ” Communication Early in his stint as the Clearwater fisheries manager, DuPont generated some angst from the public over the fickleness of spring chinook fisheries. People love to fish for the hard-fighting salmon. “They’re here for a short period of time. They’re big and they taste great. So the combination of those three things — when they are here, man, people, they’re as passionate as you can get.” But the runs are often small and seasons can sometimes end abruptly, causing frustration among anglers. “My first two years as a fisheries manager, I was very green and probably didn’t know a lot about what the public wanted and I got a lot of hate mail, more than I do now,” he said. “It got to the point where I was like, ‘All right, I need to understand what they want and I need to keep them informed about why we are doing what we are doing.’ ” He started a weekly spring chinook fishery email and, at the same time, worked with the public to develop a harvest matrix that frames season options like daily bag limits and how many days per week will be open to fishing based on run strength. The newsletter was an instant hit. He got comments like, “This is the best thing Fish and Game ever did” and “It’s about time Fish and Game started communicating with us,” he said. “That is when it really hit me that just, ‘My God, they want this information; this is important to them. They want to be kept in the loop, they want to be part of the process.’ ” The email list grew from about 200 people the first year to about 2,000. In addition, the updates are posted to the Fish and Game website as blog posts. They appear weekly during the spring chinook season, but DuPont also writes about other fisheries such as kokanee fishing at Dworshak Reservoir, steelhead forecasts, and interesting research by him and his colleagues. “I would tell any manager in the future, ‘Hey, when you become a manager, not only are you managing the fish but you’ve got to understand what the public wants and keep them involved and in the loop because they are a huge part of the picture.’ ” The harvest matrix was an attempt to satisfy as many people as possible and to make the department and the commission’s season-setting decisions more transparent. Through public meetings and surveys, DuPont said the department learned that people prefer longer seasons even if it means smaller bag limits or fishing limited to four days per week. “So, we’ve structured our fisheries now to try to extend the seasons as long as we can while still providing good opportunity.” Steelhead overhaul Under his watch and with the help of a workgroup, the state changed the structure of the steelhead fishery on the Clearwater River. For decades, most of the Clearwater was open to catch-and-release steelhead fishing from July 1 to Oct. 14. The harvest season opened on Oct. 15. But complications developed. Fall chinook became more abundant, which threatened to change the more laid-back feel of the catch-and-release season when effort is not as intense. The Oct. 15 start of the season made for good fishing for a week or two. But fishing often slowed by mid November as many of the hatchery steelhead are harvested. DuPont convened a working group made up of anglers from different factions and asked them to hammer out a different structure to the season. “We’ve had other working groups but this was the first time we had a working group that their goal was to develop a proposal for fall chinook and steelhead.” The group came up with a menu of two alternatives. One was pretty similar to the old structure. The second was a pretty radical shakeup. The harvest season would open Sept. 10 and then switch to catch-and-release on Oct. 15 and back to harvest on Nov. 9. The department shared the two alternatives with the public and ultimately recommended the radical shift that was adopted by the commission. It’s proved to be popular with many anglers. The earlier start allows people to harvest A-run fish that visit the Clearwater before leaving for other destinations. They also have a chance to catch and keep early arriving B-run steelhead, fall chinook and coho. The switch to catch-and-release retains the lower-effort steelhead fishing popular with fly anglers and others. It also allows B-run steelhead to pile up and become distributed up and down the river before harvest season reopens, solving the problem of a hot start to the harvest season followed by a crash in catch rates. A new fishing hole When DuPont took the job, Deyo Reservoir near Weippe was nothing more than an idea. It had some momentum but had not progressed much and people were wondering if it would happen. He worked with a group of people from Weippe and they decided to apply for a grant. They got it and matching money. “Now, there’s a beautiful reservoir that will be there for 100 years or more. The campground is full all summer long. To see that kind of project to fruition is pretty amazing,” he said. DuPont names sturgeon as his favorite fish and has made monitoring, managing and researching the Hells Canyon population a key focus during his time in the Clearwater Region. That work includes pioneering novel ways to help the population that is in decline. “Since I’ve been here, we’ve gone through a variety of studies, trying to understand this population to make sure that we’re doing whatever we can to make sure it’s healthy and persistent,” he said. “The work we do, not only is it fun, but it’s fascinating. And it’s meaningful and I’m still trying to spread the word to the day I leave because I think this population is going to face some significant challenges. Barker may be contacted at ebarker@lmtribune.com
summary: Joe DuPont will retire after 18 years guiding Idaho's most popular and diverse fisheries . The Clearwater Region is renowned for its salmon and steelhead fishing . The region is home to massive white sturgeon, one of the most iconic species in Columbia River Basin .

title: Strictly Come Dancing fans reel over 'absolutely ridiculous' exit spoiler
text: Fans of Strictly Come Dancing have been left absolutely stunned after this weekend's elimination spoilers have surfaced online well before Sunday evening's broadcast. Since the results are recorded on Saturday night - during which one celebrity opened up about their mum's cancer battle - audience members witnessed two pairs battle it out in the dance-off, set to air officially tonight (November 16). Year after year, the exit results have consistently leaked online hours ahead of transmission, and this weekend has followed the same pattern. Though the axed celebrity's identity is doing the rounds online, DailyStar has opted against revealing who has reportedly departed the BBC contest. Nevertheless, with the spoilers spreading across the web, devoted viewers flocked to X to voice their reactions, many left absolutely gobsmacked, reports Wales Online. One fan exclaimed: "I'm sorry what????" Another penned: "Only my opinion but I think it's one of the first times this series the wrong person has gone." A furious viewer raged: "NOOOO that's absolutely ridiculous!!! I'm so gutted and p****d off now!!" In complete shock, one person remarked: "That's a joke right?" Someone else posted: "Wrong person went this time." Another chimed in: "Really shocked. Thought the eliminated person would definitely be in the final." On Saturday evening, all remaining hopefuls gave their absolute best to wow both the panel and home audiences, desperate to secure their place in Blackpool. Right from the off, presenter Tess Daly informed audiences: "All of our remaining celebrities have already scored nines or tens so far in this series. "Everyone is worthy of dancing on that world-famous floor, but who makes it there really is down to you." Following each pair's performance on the dancefloor, it was Amber Davies and Nikita Kuzmin who wowed the judging panel the most with their fiery Paso Doble, bagging themselves a stellar score of 38. Hot on their heels were Lewis Cope and Katya Jones, who secured a brilliant total of 37 points for their sizzling Tango. Unfortunately, languishing at the foot of the leaderboard with disappointing scores of 27 are both Balvinder Sopal, Julian Caillon, Vicky Pattison and Kai Widdrington. Viewers can watch the Strictly Come Dancing results show on Sunday (November 16) on BBC One at 7:15pm.
summary: This weekend's Strictly Come Dancing elimination spoilers have surfaced online . Viewers were left absolutely gobsmacked after the results were recorded on Saturday night . One fan exclaimed: "I'm sorry what????" Another said: "Wrong person went this time"

title: Why Mukesh Ambani, Nita Ambani, Akash, Anant, Isha Ambani lives on 27th floor of Rs 150000000000 Antilia? Reason will shock you
text: Antilia is the renowned 27-story residence of Indian billionaire Mukesh Ambani, located on Altamount Road in Mumbai. It is one of the world’s most expensive private homes. The building is named after a mythological island, “Antilia,” and has become a landmark for its distinctive design, height, and extravagant interior. From the outside, the house looks like a modern high-rise. The Rs 15000 crores home includes grand ballrooms, numerous family rooms, private theaters, spas, swimming pools, gardens on multiple floors, and even a room where artificial snow falls. The house is resilient and built to withstand the strongest earthquake. With over 600 employees maintaining the luxurious home each day, Antilia also boasts a multi-level garage that accommodates several vehicles. For many, Antilia symbolizes the wealth and stature of the Ambani family and remains a source of fascination for many around the world. Regardless of the multi-story building, the Ambanis chose to live on the 27th floor of the home. The family, including Mukesh Ambani, Nita Ambani, their elder son, Akash Ambani, daughter-in-law, Shloka Mehta, and their children, Prithvi Akash Ambani and Veda Akash Ambani, all live on the 27th floor. As stated in a Times Now Hindi report, Nita Ambani stated she chose this floor chose this level to ensure that every room benefits from abundant natural light and proper ventilation. It is also reported that no one has access to the 27th floor of the building except for immediate family and friends.Add India.com as a Preferred Source About the Author Sumaila Zaman Sumaila Zaman is a Senior Sub Editor at India.com, where she covers key developments and trending events across education, world affairs, business, and current news.
