title: A brother lost too soon: A tribute to inspector Shah Asrar Ul Haq
text: We encourage you to review our Terms of Service, and Privacy Policy. By continuing, you agree to the Terms listed here. In case you want to opt out, please click "Do Not Sell or Share My Personal Information" link in the footer of this page. We won't sell or share your personal information to inform the ads you see. You may still see interest-based ads if your information is sold or shared by other companies or was sold or shared previously. There are moments in life that carve themselves so deeply into one’s memory that they alter the shape of time. Some nights refuse to fade, no matter how many dawns arrive after them. For me, the night of the Nowgam Police Station blast is one such night — a night that split my life into a before and an after. It took away not just a cousin, but the person I knew as my elder brother, my confidant, my closest companion: Inspector Asrar Ahmad Shah. This tribute is not just an obituary for a fallen officer. It is a remembrance of a life lived with integrity, humility and service. It is an attempt to capture, in mere words, the magnitude of a loss that continues to echo through our home, our extended family, and the uniformed fraternity he served with distinction. A bond beyond blood Asrar and I were cousins by relation, but brothers by heart and upbringing. We grew up together in Drugmulla, sharing the same childhood lanes, festivals, meals, mischiefs and quarrels. Over the years, that early camaraderie matured into something deeper — a bond strengthened by trust, shared experiences, and the unspoken understanding that we could turn to each other in moments of uncertainty. Our relationship grew particularly close in recent years. Life, responsibilities and career had taken us into different worlds, but somehow we kept finding our way back to each other. Asrar had a quiet habit of confiding in me. He would call at odd hours, discussing things that weighed on him, talking freely about work pressures, observations, and the difficult situations that his job in the police often placed him in. I was, in some strange but cherished way, both his sounding board and his anchor. A small but unforgettable moment came recently when I received my renewed passport. I called him to share the news, expecting a quick congratulatory remark. Instead, he insisted — rather joyfully — that I had to host a small celebration. “Gani & Sons ch party denni !” (Throw a party at Gani & Sons!) And so we did. Our entire family gathered for a casual, cheerful evening, full of laughter and warm conversations. None of us knew that night that we were creating a final memory — a moment that would soon become a precious relic of a time before tragedy arrived. The officer behind the uniform Inspector Asrar Ahmad Shah did not wear his uniform for admiration. He wore it for responsibility. Posted at the State Investigation Agency (SIA) Headquarters, Humhama, he was known for his sincerity, precision and silent dedication. He was the kind of officer who earned respect not through authority, but through character. Whenever I visited him at SIA, he introduced me to his seniors with a mixture of affection and humour: “Yeh Adnan 100 bemariyon ka ilaaj hai.” (Adnan is the cure for a hundred illnesses.) His colleagues would smile, but behind the joke was the truth — he trusted me, relied on our bond, and valued our connection. Officers who worked with him describe him using words that in today’s policing environment are rare: humble, balanced, professional, soft-spoken, reliable. His approach to work was not marked by bravado or display; he quietly completed tasks that demanded both discipline and discretion. His calm temperament made him an anchor even in high-pressure situations. The night everything changed On the night of the incident, around 11 pm, I stepped outside and heard a loud explosion in the distance. Kashmir, unfortunately, is no stranger to such sounds, yet that night, something about the blast unsettled me. I brushed it off, not knowing that life had already shifted beneath my feet. Five minutes later, a Twitter notification appeared on my phone. Journalist Ahmad Ali Fayaz had posted about a blast in Nowgam. A sense of dread washed over me. My instinct sent me straight to my phone. I called Asrar Bhai. The first call showed “busy.” The second — switched off. An inexplicable fear tightened around my chest. I immediately called his wife, Shahida, whom we affectionately call Dia. “Has Asrar reached home?” I asked. “No… not yet,” she replied softly. By then, I was already rushing towards Nowgam. Something inside me kept repeating a truth I did not want to accept: something has gone terribly wrong. On the way, I phoned my cousin Zaheer in Kupwara. My voice trembled as I said, “Leave immediately. Come to Srinagar. And don’t tell anyone anything.” I then tried calling my father multiple times. When he finally returned the call, I was crying uncontrollably. He panicked, thinking I had met with an accident. “No, Abba… not me,” I said, fighting my breath. Then came the words that broke both of us: “Asrar Bhai is no more…” My father’s silence on the phone cut deeper than any sound. Another cousin, Arif Rasool, who works for a multinational company in Srinagar, called me, asking, “Where are you? Tell me where to come.” Everyone was moving, calling, searching — yet the truth was racing ahead of all of us. I kept driving between Nowgam Police Station and Budshah Flats, where Asrar lived. My mind was in a storm — one part rushing to the station to find him, another part rushing to his home to somehow shield his wife from immediate heartbreak. I told her only that he was injured, sparing her the unbearable truth for the moment because the children were asleep. His father — our Dadijaan — reached the Police Control Room (PCR) soon after. I held his hand and repeated the only thing I could: “We haven’t found him yet, but we heard he might be injured.” It was a sentence made of hope, fear and denial. We lived that way till 8 in the morning — suspended between the faint hope that he might still be alive and the crushing fear that he was gone. At 8 am, I finally went to Budshah Flats again. This time, I sat with his father and gently told him what I had known in my heart since midnight: “Dadijaan… it is possible we have lost Asrar.” That moment broke him — and broke all of us in ways words cannot fully capture. A confirmation no family deserves The requirement for DNA sampling at that stage confirmed what none of us wanted to believe. Nothing prepares a family for that kind of news — not in Kashmir, not anywhere in the world. After that, everything turned into a blur — of grief, of silence, of formalities, of prayers, and of an aching emptiness that began settling into our home. What remains vivid, however, are the extraordinary gestures of compassion shown in the hours that followed. The police force stands with us Senior officers of the Jammu & Kashmir Police visited our home in Drugmulla soon after the tragedy. Their presence was not ceremonial; it was human, empathetic and deeply felt. DGP Nalin Prabhat, in particular, said something to me that has stayed etched in my memory: “It has been a year since I took charge, and I did not know him personally. But what I have heard about Inspector Asrar from different officers is mind-blowing.” Coming from the highest-ranking officer in the police hierarchy, this was not merely a condolence — it was an acknowledgement of Asrar’s character, professionalism and silent contributions. It affirmed something I already knew: he was respected not just by those close to him, but across the ranks. A life of service, a legacy of integrity Inspector Asrar Ahmad Shah was many things: A devoted police officer. A loving husband. A caring father. A dutiful son. A steadfast friend. And for me — a brother. His life was anchored in qualities that seem almost old-fashioned today: sincerity, humility, discipline and an unwavering sense of responsibility. He approached his work with quiet dignity and his family with tender devotion. He never boasted of his achievements. In fact, he rarely spoke about himself at all. His integrity did not need a spotlight; it revealed itself through actions—in the way he handled difficult assignments, supported his colleagues, or patiently navigated complex situations. His death is not merely a personal loss for our family. It is a loss for the police force and for the society he served. Officers like him are not easily found—men who wear the uniform not for power, but for purpose; not for recognition, but for responsibility. The final goodbye On the day of his funeral, I was overwhelmed by a strange, painful realisation: God had chosen me to accompany him from the first moment of the tragedy to the last moment at the graveyard. I was the one who waited for him that night, expecting him to return from duty. I was the one who received his body. I was the one who walked with him to his final resting place. I was the one who lowered him gently into the grave, handing him back to the Almighty. It was the heaviest honour of my life—one that will stay with me forever. Gone too soon, remembered forever “Asrar Bhai Gone Too Soon” is not just a headline. It is the truth of our lives now. He left us quietly, abruptly, painfully—but he left behind a legacy that will continue to guide us. His children will grow up knowing their father was a man of honour. His wife will forever carry the strength he admired in her. His parents will remember him with pride. His colleagues will recall him as a rare officer who embodied integrity without noise. And I—I will remember him as the boy I grew up with, the man who trusted me with every thought, and the brother whose absence has carved a silence in my days. May Allah grant him the highest place in Jannah. May He give patience and strength to his family, his friends and everyone whose life he touched. Ameen. Views expressed above are the author's own. summary: The night of the Nowgam Police Station blast is one such night that split my life into a before and after . It took away not just a cousin, but the person I knew as my elder brother, my confidant, my closest companion: Inspector Asrar Ahmad Shah . This tribute is not just an obituary for a fallen officer, it is a remembrance of a life lived with integrity, humility and service .

title: Insecurity: Kefas Shuts Down Boarding Schools In Taraba
text: Taraba State Governor, Agbu Kefas, has ordered all secondary schools both public and private to immediately send their boarding students home following heightened security threats across the country. The directive was issued in a statement signed by the State Commissioner for Education, Dr. Augustina Godwin. She stated that the rising wave of insecurity has made boarding students vulnerable to targeted attacks by bandits, citing the recent abductions of schoolgirls in Kebbi and Niger states as worrying indicators. READ ALSO: According to Dr. Godwin, Kefas has now directed that all secondary schools in the state operate strictly as day schools until security conditions improve. School principals and private school owners have been instructed to commence immediate deboarding of students. She explained that the measure is a proactive step to protect students’ lives and prevent potential security incidents amid escalating unrest nationwide. The Taraba State Government assured parents of its commitment to restoring safety and stability. It also pledged stronger collaboration with security agencies to address emerging threats, while urging all school authorities to fully comply with the directive and strengthen internal security on their premises.
summary: The directive was issued in a statement signed by the State Commissioner for Education, Dr. Augustina Godwin . She stated that the rising wave of insecurity has made boarding students vulnerable to targeted attacks by bandits . The Taraba State Government assured parents of its commitment to restoring safety and stability .

title: Nigeria school attacks: 215 students kidnapped from Catholic school amid outrage over violence against Christians
text: Police in Nigeria’s north-central Niger State reported that a group of armed bandits invaded a private Catholic school abducting hundreds of schoolchildren early on Friday, amid widespread outrage over violence against Christians in the West African nation. Despite some students managing to get to safety during the attack, the Christian Association of Nigeria (CAN) said 215 students and 12 teachers were abducted in the raid. Parents have been arriving at the school to pick their children up, ahead of the school shutting down, CAN’s Niger State chapter chairman Most. Rev. Bulus Dauwa Yohanna said. Yohanna, who visited the school and met parents of the abducted children, said the association was working with the government and security agencies to bring the children back safely, according to his spokesman. Christian Association of Nigeria The abduction in Niger, which borders Nigeria’s capital, Abuja, follows a similar attack on a church by gunmen in neighboring Kwara State earlier in the week. During the church attack, at least two people were killed, and several worshippers, including the pastor, were abducted. In addition, this week, armed men kidnapped 25 female students when they stormed a government girls’ boarding school in northwestern Kebbi State. Tragically, the school’s vice principal was shot and killed during this attack. The Niger State government condemned the latest attack on St. Mary’s School, stating that “the exact number of abducted pupils is yet to be confirmed.” The Niger State police command issued a statement Friday indicating that security forces have deployed to the area and are “combing the forests” in an effort to rescue the abducted students. Nigeria is currently facing a concerning wave of attacks by armed groups that target vulnerable civilian populations and orchestrate mass abductions for ransom. The country is also plagued by religiously motivated attacks and other violent conflicts stemming from communal and ethnic tensions, as well as disputes between farmers and herders over limited access to land and water resources. US President Donald Trump has frequently expressed outrage over disputed allegations of a “mass slaughter” of Christians by Islamist insurgents in Nigeria and has threatened military action to protect this religious group. Earlier this month, Trump designated Nigeria as a “Country of Particular Concern” under the US International Religious Freedom Act, suggesting that his administration has determined Nigeria has engaged in or tolerated “systematic, ongoing, (and) egregious violations of religious freedom.” The recent string of attacks coincides with the arrival of a Nigerian delegation in Washington for discussions with US government officials. A Pentagon official confirmed a meeting that took place on Thursday between Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth and Nigeria’s National Security Adviser, Mallam Nuhu Ribadu. Additionally, the Nigerian delegation is scheduled to meet Deputy Secretary of State Christopher Landau on Friday, according to a State Department spokesperson.
summary: Police in Nigeria's north-central Niger State report that armed bandits invaded a private Catholic school abducting hundreds of schoolchildren early on Friday . The Christian Association of Nigeria said 215 students and 12 teachers were abducted in the raid . Nigeria is currently facing a concerning wave of attacks by armed groups that target vulnerable civilian populations and orchestrate mass abductions for ransom .

title: East Valley overcomes Lynden to reach Class 2A semifinals for first time since 2004
text: East Valley’s Cody Gasseling, right, celebrates after running for a first down late in the fourth quarter to end the game against Lynden Saturday, Nov. 22, 2025, in Yakima, Wash. Call it a perk of a truly dominating season, but No. 3 East Valley trailed only fleetingly during an undefeated run to its Saturday Class 2A state quarterfinal. With 10 of its 11 wins by 23 points or more, it was fair to wonder how the Red Devils would meet the moment when they matched up with a fellow state championship contender. The second of two long, morale-draining scoring drives gave No. 6 Lynden a touchdown lead with 31 seconds left in the first half and provided EV with that very inflection point. Finally challenged. What would be the response? The Red Devils answered emphatically. And, most critically, quickly. Senior quarterback Jaxon Berg needed only three plays to orchestrate a scoring drive, connecting with Cody Gasseling for a 31-yard score to spark a 27-24 come-from-behind victory at West Valley's Clasen Field as EV continued to generate chunk plays on offense and slow a methodical, pounding Lynden rushing attack in the second half. "We had a lot of things that didn't go our way, and we haven't had that necessarily this season," EV coach Eric Berg said. "For that to happen tonight, and for these kids to come through and do what they did today, that was pretty amazing." An errant extra-point snap kept Lynden ahead at intermission, and the Lions added to their advantage with a 39-yard field goal after the Red Devils were unable score on four tries from inside the 2 on their first possession of the new half. East Valley’s Cody Gasseling scores a touchdown against Lynden in a 2A state quarterfinal game Saturday, Nov. 22, 2025, in Yakima, Wash. But again EV (12-0) responded promptly. Gasseling, taking on a larger role in the run game with starting running back Braden Albrecht limited due to injury, ripped off a 40-yard run. And after a rare incompletion, Berg hit Greyson Stevens on a screen pass and the Montana State commit darted 27 yards for East Valley's first lead of the game. Stevens also set up EV's first score with a long punt return and snagged five of Berg's nine completions on 14 attempts. The 6-foot-2, 230-pound Gasseling, who's listed as a tight end, again proved to be a more-than-capable fill-in for Albrecht, rushing for 126 yards on 16 carries a week after rumbling for 133 and a pair of scores. "He's a beast," Jaxon Berg said. "He's getting so much better at reading holes, putting his shoulder down and running through people." He found the end zone twice on the ground again Saturday, capping an all-run, 11-play, 66-yard drive with a two-yard score to put EV up 27-17 with less than eight minutes left in the fourth quarter. "Three to four yards is fine for us every play," Gasseling said, alluding to the methodical nature of the drive. "Credit to our offensive line. We just ate." Lynden, which has played in the last six quarterfinals and won 10 state titles since 1980, quickly moved to claw back in the game. Quarterback Lukas Lalji connected with Samm Puello Arango for a 60-yard score, the duo's second touchdown of the day, to pull within three. East Valley’s Zeliah Wade sacks Lynden’s Lukas Lalji in a 2A state quarterfinal game Saturday, Nov. 22, 2025, in Yakima, Wash. Lalji and Co. had a shot to retake the lead after the Lions forced a three-and-out. But backed up to the 4-yard-line by an excellent Stevens punt and pressured by CWAC defensive MVP Zeliah Wade, the speedy QB who rushed for 169 yards and a first-quarter touchdown was unable to move the chains. All that stood between East Valley and its first semifinal trip since 2004 was a first down, and Gasseling appeared to pick it up with a third-down run, but a penalty for aiding the runner moved the Red Devils back to third-and-6. A four-yard Gasseling gain and Lynden's last timeout set up a fourth-and-2 for the ballgame. Eric Berg again turned to Gasseling, who was marked down right at the line to gain, necessitating a measurement by the chain gang. East Valley’s Greyson Stevens stiff-arms Lynden’s Lawsen DeBoer on his way to a touchdown in a 2A state quarterfinal game Saturday, Nov. 22, 2025, in Yakima, Wash. "The whole game flashed before my eyes," said Albrecht, a captain who gritted his way to 12 carries for 24 yards and key tackles on defense while clearly playing at less than full strength. "I was fully ready to jump up and down, and I was fully ready to run back out there on defense and give it everything I had for that last minute." The chains stretched, and EV was awarded a first down. By an inch. Or maybe a millimeter. The margin matters little to a program enjoying a generational season fueled by some of the Valley's most productive players. Berg's two TD passes were his 89th and 90th of his high school career, the fourth-most in Valley history, while Stevens is one of four players in Valley history with more than 3,500 receiving yards. They'll get a chance to add to their historic tallies and reach the school's third state title game with a semifinal matchup Nov. 29 at No. 2 Tumwater, which beat No. 7 Franklin Pierce 27-6 in its quarterfinal. "It means everything to me," Albrecht said while holding back tears. "To be able to go out and play with my brothers one more week, I don't care if it's only one more week. I'm putting my life out on the line, that's my mindset. Leave everything out there." The second of two long, morale-draining scoring drives gave No. 6 Lynden a touchdown lead with 31 seconds left in the first half . But again EV (12-0) responded promptly . Senior quarterback Jaxon Berg needed only three plays to orchestrate a scoring drive, connecting with Cody Gasseling for 31-yard score .

title: 22-year-old suspect arrested after fatal shooting at Hanks Drive apartment complex
text: A 22-year-old Baton Rouge man was arrested for allegedly shooting a man at the La Playa Place apartment complex on Hanks Drive this Thursday. Darrel Thomas, 20, was booked into the East Baton Rouge Parish jail on a count each of second-degree murder, illegal carrying of weapons and possession of more than 14 grams of marijuana. East Baton Rouge Parish Sheriff's deputies were originally called to the La Playa Place complex shortly before 9 p.m. on Thursday after a ShotSpotter device reported possible gunshots in the area. Upon arrival, deputies located a man suffering from multiple gunshot wounds on the sidewalk inside the complex. EMS treated the man, who succumbed to his injuries and died. Deputies found multiple firearm casings near the victim's body, as well as other spent casings near the front doors of two nearby apartment units. The casings were of assorted calibers. A white Honda Civic, which was parked near these units, also appeared to be struck by gunshots. CCTV footage from the apartment showed the Civic was parked outside of the apartment complex for around 15 minutes. The footage also showed multiple unidentified people discharging firearms near the Civic and the apartment units' front doors. Homicide detectives with EBRSO returned to the complex with a search warrant for those units on Friday morning, according to an affidavit for Thomas's arrest. Inside, they located Thomas and another man with the same last name, Matalius Thomas, 21, in a back bedroom. Five firearms were located in the same bedroom, three of which were Glock handguns. Over 20 grams of marijuana were also seized from the same room. The two men were arrested on counts of illegal carrying of weapons and possession of marijuana. Later, detectives interviewed witnesses who identified Darrell Thomas as being a suspect in the homicide. Darrell Thomas was allegedly armed with a Glock handgun and seen firing on the victim from near his unit's front door. The witness said Darrell Thomas went inside the unit after the shooting. While witnesses said Darrell Thomas didn't live at La Playa Place, police records show his address as being at the complex. Witness statements were consistent with CCTV footage of the shooting, the arrest warrant said. Firearms collected inside the apartment unit are currently being analyzed at the Louisiana State Police Crime Lab alongside the spent cartridges from the shooting. The victim in this shooting has yet to be identified by the East Baton Rouge Parish Sheriff's Office. Email Quinn Coffman at quinn.coffman@theadvocate.com.
summary: Darrel Thomas, 20, was booked into the East Baton Rouge Parish jail on a count each of second-degree murder, illegal carrying of weapons and possession of more than 14 grams of marijuana . He was arrested for allegedly shooting a man at the La Playa Place apartment complex on Hanks Drive this Thursday .

title: Hundreds protest in Tunisia over president's escalating crackdown on freedoms
text: People take part in a protest against Tunisian president Kais Saied’s rule and demanding the release of political prisoners in Tunis, Tunisia, Saturday, Nov. 22, 2025. (AP Photo/Anis Mili) A man holds a smoke flare to protest against pollution caused by a phosphate plant in the south of Tunisia, during a protest against Tunisian president Kais Saied’s rule and demanding the release of political prisoners, in Tunis, Tunisia, Saturday, Nov. 22, 2025. (AP Photo/Anis Mili) People take part in a protest against Tunisian president Kais Saied’s rule and demanding the release of political prisoners in Tunis, Tunisia, Saturday, Nov. 22, 2025. Banner in Arabic reads “7 minutes = trial duration.” (AP Photo/Anis Mili) People take part in a protest against Tunisian president Kais Saied’s rule and demanding the release of political prisoners in Tunis, Tunisia, Saturday, Nov. 22, 2025. (AP Photo/Anis Mili) People take part in a protest against Tunisian president Kais Saied’s rule and demanding the release of political prisoners in Tunis, Tunisia, Saturday, Nov. 22, 2025. (AP Photo/Anis Mili) TUNIS, Tunisia (AP) — Tunisians took to the streets of downtown Tunis on Saturday over what they described as President Kais Saied ’s increasingly authoritarian rule and demanding the release of all jailed political prisoners. The rally, held under the banner “Against Injustice,” brought together families of political detainees and activists from different ideological backgrounds. The demonstration drew more than 1,000 protesters, some dressed in black and chanting anti-regime slogans, including “The people want to overthrow the regime,” “What a great country! Oppression and tyranny!” and “No fear no terror, the street belongs to the people.” The protest came as part of a broader surge in protests nationwide over political and economic turmoil under Saied’s rule. On Thursday, Tunisian journalists protested against the widening crackdown on the freedom of the press and the temporary suspension of several prominent civil society organizations. Protesters also called out Saied’s interference in the judiciary and accused him of using the police to target political opponents. Ayoub Amara, one of the organizers, told reporters on Saturday that the protest aimed to highlight the plight of those held in Tunisian prisons for their political opinions. He said it also touched on other broader grievances, including environmental protests convulsing the phosphate-producing city of Gabes and arbitrary arrests under anti-terrorism laws. “All the progress of the past 14 years has been overturned,” Amara said. “ Tunisia is big enough for all Tunisians, and no single person can rule it according to his whims.” Monia Brahim, the wife of jailed opposition figure Abdelhamid Jlassi, said she joined the march because she believes “many Tunisians are facing deep injustice.” “I came to defend my rights as a citizen,” she told The Associated Press. “Political prisoners know for a fact that they are in prison to pay the price for their principles, their constitutional right for civil and political activism, and are being held hostage by the regime established today in Tunisia.” Among those detained, some are currently on hunger strike including constitutional law professor Jawher Ben Mbarek who has been striking for over 20 days. Several rights groups have raised increasing alarm over the growing scale of repression in Tunisia. Human Rights Watch has said that over 50 people, including politicians, lawyers, journalists and activists, have been subjected to arbitrary arrest or prosecution since late 2022, for exercising their rights to freedom of expression, peaceful assembly or political activity. The rights group also warned that broad anti-terrorism and cybercrime laws were being utilized to criminalize dissent and tame all forms of free speech. Saied, who suspended parliament and consolidated all branches of power in July 2021, said his actions were necessary to root out corruption, eliminate “traitors” and restore state institutions.
summary: Tunisians took to the streets of downtown Tunis on Saturday over what they described as President Kais Saied ’s increasingly authoritarian rule . The rally, held under the banner “Against Injustice,” brought together families of political detainees and activists from different ideological backgrounds . The demonstration drew more than 1,000 protesters, some dressed in black and chanting anti-regime slogans .

title: Dear Abby: I yelled at daughter’s bum boyfriend 6 years ago and he’s still mad about it
text: DEAR ABBY: My daughter is asking me to apologize to her boyfriend, “Harry,” for yelling at him when I was helping them move six years ago. (I had traveled 250 miles to help.) The day of the move, Harry didn’t take the day off work, so he wasn’t there to help. (They had a second-floor unit with no elevator.) When he finally did show up, he proceeded to slow-walk taking out the recycling stuff. At the new place, Harry helped somewhat, but when the food was delivered, rather than continue to help, he decided to sit down and eat while the other two helpers and I continued moving stuff in. (This was 10 hours into the move.) That’s when I lost it. I yelled at him for not helping more. All he had done in his relationship with my daughter was go to work, come home and play video games. He didn’t help around the house or show any interest in helping with their son. Over the last few years, Harry has changed somewhat in helping with his son, but my daughter now feels stuck in the middle and wants me to apologize to him for yelling. I have made no disparaging remarks about him since. I even liked some of his posts on Facebook. I have gotten over it, but it seems Harry hasn’t. I told my daughter he needs professional help. The last time I visited, he stayed in a hotel for the weekend. My son says it should be an apology going both ways and should come from Harry first. What do you think? -- FAMILY DILEMMA IN CANADA DEAR FAMILY DILEMMA: Face it. Your daughter’s boyfriend is an overgrown child. Count your blessings that she isn’t married to him. Someone has to be an adult, and I am voting for you to fill that role by taking the first step. Hold your nose and apologize to Harry, if only for your daughter’s sake. Dear Abby is written by Abigail Van Buren, also known as Jeanne Phillips, and was founded by her mother, Pauline Phillips. Contact Dear Abby at or P.O. Box 69440, Los Angeles, CA 90069. Jeanne Phillips, also known as Abigail Van Buren, has written the advice column “Dear Abby” since 2000, responding knowledgeably with the wit and compassion that earns her the loyalty of millions of fans. summary: The day of the move, Harry didn't take the day off work, so he wasn't there to help . At the new place, Harry helped somewhat, but when the food was delivered, rather than continue to help, he decided to sit down and eat . That’s when I lost it. I yelled at him for not helping more. He didn’t help around the house or show any interest in helping with their son .

title: Strictly Come Dancing fans have same complaint as La Voix withdraws from show 'Pointless!'
text: Strictly Come Dancing fans have been left with the same question after it was announced La Voix has withdrawn from the competition. During Saturday (November 22) night's show, the remaining contestants took to the dance floor at the iconic Blackpool Tower Ballroom. Before things kicked off for Blackpool Week, presenter Tess Daly informed viewers that the drag queen – real name Chris Dennis – would not be returning to the competition after sustaining a foot injury. She said: "We can confirm she has very sadly had to withdraw from the competition," before revealing there would be no elimination this weekend. But this has left fans wondering why Sunday night's show is still airing now that there is no dance-off. Taking to social media with their queries, one wrote: "So what’s the point of Sunday’s show when everything can be done tonight #Strictly?" Read more: Strictly pro says only one person can replace Craig Revel Horwood Read more: BBC Strictly viewers switch off as major star pulls out of show We use your sign-up to provide content in ways you've consented to and to improve our understanding of you. This may include adverts from us and 3rd parties based on our understanding. You can unsubscribe at any time. Read our Privacy Policy Another declared: "Why is there still a show on Sunday night this week? No elimination, no show needed!" A third said: "Ngl it's boring if no one goes. What's the Sunday show gonna be?" Another added: "Tomorrow's "results show" will probably just be the judges waffling for 45 minutes?" A fifth echoed: "How will they fill tomorrow? They got 45 minutes to fill with two dances and one judges chat." An additional fan raged: "They’ve announced nobody will be going home this week, yet they’ve said they’ll be speaking to La Voix in tomorrow’s results show. What results exactly? How about saving some license fee money and just not having a show rather than spaffing cash on an hour of filler?" Someone else agreed: "No one’s leaving Strictly this week. Makes tomorrow’s results show a bit pointless doesn’t it really." However, there will be plenty to look forward to for fans, as Lewis Capaldi will be performing. Former finalists Danny Mac, Jay McGuiness, Ashley Roberts and Layton Williams will return to the dancefloor for a group routine at Blackpool, each revisiting one of their most famous Strictly moments. Tess and Claudia Winkleman will also receive an update from La Voix and her professional partner Aljaž Škorjanec following their departure. The TV star was granted a bye to next weekend after sustaining a foot injury, but was later informed that she would no longer be able to continue in the competition. In a statement, the 45-year-old said: "With the guidance of the medical team and a heavy, heavy heart I have to officially withdraw from Strictly Come Dancing. What upsets me most is feeling like I’ve let my wonderful partner, Aljaž Škorjanec, down." Expressing gratitude to Aljaž for believing in her from the beginning, La Voix added: "I’m devastated not to be able to continue the adventure with him, but I’m endlessly grateful for everything he’s given me throughout this experience."
summary: Strictly Come Dancing fans have been left with the same question after it was announced La Voix has withdrawn from the show . The drag queen – real name Chris Dennis – sustained a foot injury . Tess Daly said there would be no dance-off this weekend but this has left fans wondering why Sunday night's show is still airing . One wrote: "Why is there still a show on Sunday night this week?"

title: NFL’s heaviest quarterback won Super Bowl ring and reached 560lbs before tragic death aged 38
text: Jared Lorenzen will go down as a University of Kentucky great. The towering quarterback was a formidable presence at 6 ft 4in and 285lbs. His size and the fact he threw left-handed earned him the Hefty Lefty moniker as the NFL's heaviest ever quarterback. As a high school senior at Highlands in Fort Thomas, Kentucky, he racked up passing 3,393 yards, 45 touchdowns and six interceptions, adding 904 yards and 15 scores on the ground in a 15-0 season. It saw him land an offer from the University of Kentucky and the Johnny Unitas Golden Arm Award. Per ESPN, Unitas attended the presentation and told the youngster: "You're awfully big to be a quarterback. I don't think you're going to amount to much of anything being that big." Despite turmoil at head coach, by the time he left in 2007 Lorenzen held Wildcats records in total offense, passing yards, and passing touchdowns. "He had such a quick release and such a strong arm, it was obvious to me," said Hal Mumme, who recruited him. "Everything you could measure a quarterback by, he had. "You just had to get past the fact that he looked like an offensive lineman." For a man of his size, Lorenzen was blessed with a remarkable skill set. "His stardom would've been colossal if social media existed when he played in college," fellow Kentucky quarterback Shane Boyd said. "When you look at his stature and what he could do on the field, it was amazing to watch. It would've even been that much bigger now." "He was doing things a lot like Patrick Mahomes is doing now," added Mumme. "In a lot of ways, I think Jared broke the ground for a lot of big guys who wanted to be quarterback. Cam Newton and others like that." Lorenzen signed with the New York Giants as an undrafted free agent and by the 2006 season had won the job as Eli Manning's backup -- converting a QB sneak on third-and-one in his only play of the campaign. In the 2007 season, Lorenzen took over from the injured Manning in a game against the Dallas Cowboys to complete his first pass and watched the Giants stun the undefeated New England Patriots in Super Bowl XLII. After a brief spell with the Indianapolis Colts, where he tipped the scales at 303lbs, the passer played indoor football in the AF2, Ultimate Indoor Football League (UIFL), and Continental Indoor Football League from 2009, but his weight was a consistent issue. Lorenzen spoke to ESPN in 2014 and 2018 after an ankle injury that ended his playing career led to him hitting around 560lbs and receiving a warning from his doctor about his health. "At first it was like, once I come back from this, once I can run again and feel better about my ankle, I gotta do something," he revealed. "And then it was, man, it's cold now, and I can't really do much on it. I can walk, but it's like whoop, it inflates right away. But it's a double-edged sword. "Yeah, it inflates because I probably have more weight on it than I should, and I need to lose the weight. Well, in order to lose the weight, I have to be able to work out. Which is, you know, what you're constantly fighting." Ranking the top 10...... Quarterbacks of all-time - Can anyone better Tom Brady? Wide receivers of all-time - Does Randy Moss or Jerry Rice come out on top? Running backs of all-time - Stacking Jim Brown, Barry Sanders, Walter Payton, Emmitt Smith and more Tight ends of all-time - How does Travis Kelce compare? Lorenzen had two daughters with his high school sweetheart Tamara, but they divorced in 2013 after 18 years together. "We're best friends. She's awesome," Jared says. "But being divorced, that got me where it's just chomp-chomp-chomp-chomp. Who do I have to live for? Chomp-chomp-chomp." He was determined not to give up and in 2017 he launched The Jared Lorenzen Project where he wrote about his battle with obesity. By 2018, he had lost over 100lbs. "It turns out if you put your body through hell for about 15 years, it doesn't want to fight back," he told For the Win. "I still have these dreams I can do what I used to and it's not necessarily true. I put my body through a little bit too much too fast and had to recover from it." Tragically, the kind-hearted QB passed away a year later from an acute infection Dad Joe discussed his son's passing with Bleacher Report in 2019. "I don't think he had any idea he was as sick as he was," he said. "Everything was such a gradual progression. I knew what kind of pain he was in, but I don't think he had any idea that things were dire. As a parent, you lose sleep over that. "For the rest of my life, I will have to wish I would've done something more." Lorenzen brought a lot joy to the world before his death. "I miss him so much," added his dad. "But I couldn't be any prouder of who he was. "I'm proud of his athletic accomplishments, but I'm prouder of the person he was. For wanting people to be happy." Stay up to date with the latest from the NFL across all platforms - follow our dedicated talkSPORT USA Facebook page and subscribe to our talkSPORT USA YouTube channel for news, exclusive interviews and more.
summary: Jared Lorenzen is the NFL's heaviest ever quarterback . Lorenzen was 6 ft 4in and 285lbs at 6ft 4in at the height of his high school career . The New York Giants quarterback was drafted by the Giants in 2006 . By the time he left in 2007 Lorenzen held Wildcats records in total offense, passing yards and touchdowns .

title: Asking Eric: I’m dreading family holiday parties this year as they’re bound to be filled with political complaining
text: Dear Eric: With the holidays approaching, I’m facing a dilemma. Politically, I guess I’m a Libertarian because I am somewhere in the middle, not far left or right. That’s one reason I don’t like discussing politics, as most people who do are at one of the extremes. The other reason is it’s almost always a very negative narrative against the other side, rather than what they believe is positive about their own side. My dilemma is about Christmas. I’m from a very small family and have only a few cousins left. I’m invited each year to a cousin’s home for a lovely dinner party. I’m considering not going (i.e. staying home alone) this year because they are very liberal and very vocal about it. If I don’t chime right in with the Trump-bashing, which will be over the top this year, they accuse me of being a Trump supporter. (I have never voted for him.) I just don’t like the tone it sets at a festive time of year, and I choose not to participate. We’re getting older and it may be the last time I see some of them, but the political rants just squash the spirit of the season. I feel I can’t say anything because it’s their home and their party. How do you suggest I navigate this? – No Grinches Dear No Grinches: While it’s true that it’s their home, as a guest and as a family member, you can ask for what you need in order to feel comfortable and welcome. Start with a phone call. Tell them you value them and want to spend time with them, but that you find that the political debate wears on you and detracts from the holiday. Don’t get into the who-said-what of it all. For the moment, let’s leave voting records out of it. This is a conversation about how to have a conversation. Ask them if they’d consider focusing on family, connectivity and celebration this year. Now, some families connect and celebrate by debating. And maybe everyone in your family is like this, save for you. It’s still possible to modulate. But it’s going to take a conscious awareness of the patterns they fall into and a mutual decision to try something new. Send questions to R. Eric Thomas at eric@askingeric.com or P.O. Box 22474, Philadelphia, PA 19110. Follow him on Instagram and sign up for his weekly newsletter at rericthomas.com. R. Eric Thomas (he/him) is a national bestselling author, playwright, and screenwriter. summary: Eric: I'm from a very small family and have only a few cousins left . I'm invited each year to a cousin’s home for a dinner party for a lovely dinner party . I’m considering not going (i.e. staying home alone) this year because they are very liberal and very vocal about it . If I don’t chime right in with the Trump-bashing, which will be over the top this year, they accuse me of being a Trump supporter .

title: Cougs drop road matchup to No. 21 James Madison
text: Much like Bill Murray’s character from “Groundhog Day,” the Washington State Cougars seem to be stuck in a loop. The last four WSU losses have each felt the same — a blown fourth-quarter lead, a few too many penalties and costly quarterback mistakes. Two uncharacteristic explosive plays allowed by the WSU defense and a stale second-half offense led the Cougars to a 24-20 loss to No. 21 James Madison on Saturday in Harrisonburg, Va. “We played well enough to win this game, we just didn’t,” WSU coach Jimmy Rogers said. “As I told the guys in the locker room, ‘One opportunity left to make this season, and be bowl eligible and have an opportunity to play with each other one more time,’ and I think that’s important.” The Cougars dropped to 5-6 overall and will next host Oregon State on Saturday in Pullman. The Beavers beat WSU 10-7 on Nov. 1 in Corvallis. Another stale second half Asked about WSU’s three-point second half compared to 17 points scored in the first, Cougar quarterback Zevi Eckhaus wanted to make one thing clear in his postgame news conference. “How many drives did we have in the second half?” Eckhaus said. “Three drives in the second half, one of which we started at the (WSU) 7-yard line. It doesn’t mean we can’t score, but it makes it a lot harder.” WSU punted on that first drive, scored a field goal to go up 20-17 on its second possession of the second half, then came up short on one final drive. JMU dominated the time of possession with nearly 35 minutes of offense. While the Dukes were scoreless on their second-half opening series, the drive drained almost 10 minutes off the clock. With a 17-10 halftime lead, the Cougars seemed to keep their offense conservative in an effort to drain the clock. That plan worked in a 20-3 win at Colorado State on Sept. 27 when the offense scored just three points in the second half, but JMU proved too good to let WSU get away with that. The Cougars opted to run the ball 16 times over their three second-half drives. It netted 35 yards. Facing fourth-and-5 at his own 45, Eckhaus’ pass bounced off of wide receiver Jeremiah Noga’s helmet and the Dukes got the ball back and got the final first down they needed to kneel out the clock and improve to 10-1. “Obviously, I would love to score 20 points in the first (half) and 20 points in the second. It just hasn’t been that way for us this season,” Rogers said. “Some of that is due to playcalling, some of that is due to lack of execution, some of that is due to penalties. So, we need to continue to get better. There’s nobody who feels like the blame is on them as much as I do and we need to be hungry to finish out the season.” Francl’s big day WSU linebacker Caleb Francl stuffed the Dukes on a fourth-and-1 attempt at the WSU 7 to halt a nearly 10-minute second-half opening drive. The senior linebacker also intercepted JMU quarterback Alonza Barnett III’s first pass of the day to set up WSU’s 3-0 first-quarter lead. Francl said that the Cougs had been working on getting a jump on balls in the air by reading the QB’s eyes and anticipating opportunities. The senior said he jumped on the first pass out of Barnett’s hands sooner than he may have earlier in the year. Francl made eight total tackles, five solo, and picked off a pass in an all-around excellent day for the South Dakota State transfer. Fellow SDSU transfers Matt Durrance and Tucker Large made eight and seven tackles, respectively, on a day in which the defense forced five consecutive stops and prevented points on six of JMU’s first seven drives of the game. Despite the overall stout defensive performance and the Cougars’ emphasis and ledger of limiting explosive plays, JMU scored two touchdowns off chunk plays. The Dukes cashed in on a 68-yard touchdown pass in the third quarter and a 58-yard rushing touchdown in the fourth to take a 24-20 lead with 6:24 left. Up-and-down QB play The Dukes’ defense lifted up their offense when junior cornerback Justin Eaglin jumped an errant Eckhaus pass intended for senior wide receiver Josh Meredith and returned it 37 yards for a touchdown and a 10-3 Dukes lead early in the second quarter. Eckhaus led the Cougars on two touchdown drives to cap the first half, finding Tony Freeman on a 48-yard pass to make it 10-10. On their next drive, Eckhaus dodged defenders on his way to a 4-yard rushing touchdown to complete a 10-play, 67-yard series that spanned nearly five minutes. The Cougars gained just 20 more yards after falling behind with 6:24 left in the fourth quarter. Eckhaus completed 19-of-31 passes for 171 yards with one passing touchdown, one rushing touchdown and an interception. “There were some plays in there that he made that were really special plays,” Rogers said of Eckhaus. “Obviously, I know he’s gonna want the turnover back and a couple throws that he’s gonna want back, but that comes with playing quarterback.” Eckhaus has thrown two touchdowns and five interceptions combined during WSU’s last three losses, all on the road: 22-20 to No. 18 Virginia, 10-7 to Oregon State and the four-point loss to James Madison. WSU fell one game below .500 and needs to beat Oregon State in its regular-season finale in order to secure a bowl game. “It’s not my last game as a Coug if we win,” Eckhaus said. “(If) we do our job, we give ourselves another opportunity to play and I think that a lot of guys deserve that opportunity.” No. 21 James Madison 24, Washington State 20 First Quarter WSU — FG Stevens 29, 8:06. JMU — FG Suarez 45, 5:10. Second Quarter JMU — Eaglin 37 interception return (Suarez kick), 13:27. WSU — Freeman 48 pass from Eckhaus (Stevens kick), 7:26. WSU — Eckhaus 4 run (Stevens kick), :48. Third Quarter JMU — Wisloski 68 pass from Barnett (Suarez kick), 2:15. Fourth Quarter WSU — FG Stevens 36, 9:24. JMU — Knight 58 run (Suarez kick), 6:24. A — 25,156. INDIVIDUAL STATISTICS RUSHING — Washington St., Vorhees 19-61, Woods 10-43, Eckhaus 7-26, Pulalasi 1-0. James Madison, Knight 15-126, Barnett 7-32, Malary 6-17, Pettaway 1-4, (Team) 3-(minus 4). PASSING — Washington St., Eckhaus 19-31-1-171. James Madison, Barnett 9-18-1-144. RECEIVING — Washington St., Freeman 6-81, Woods 3-28, Leckner 3-22, Meredith 3-21, Noga 1-6, Pabst 1-6, Neal 1-4, Johnson 1-3. James Madison, Sanchez 2-24, Dippre 2-14, Wisloski 1-68, Kyle 1-18, Collins 1-11, Scott 1-5, DeGennaro 1-4. MISSED FIELD GOALS — None. Taylor can be reached at 208-848-2268, staylor@lmtribune.com, or on X or Instagram @Sam_C_Taylor.
summary: Washington State Cougars lost 24-20 to No. 21 James Madison in Harrisonburg, Va. The Cougars dropped to 5-6 overall and will next host Oregon State on Saturday in Pullman . Coach Jimmy Rogers: "We played well enough to win this game, we just didn’t"

title: Police hunt for driver who fled breath test near Devonport
text: Updated – Saturday, 8:20pm: A female driver is in custody after being intercepted by police at Wesley Vale in the state’s north west, police say. As a result of information provided by a member of the public, the woman was safely intercepted by police in Mill Road near the intersection of Moorland Beach Road a short time ago. Police have thanked members of the public for their information and assistance, saying investigations into the incident are continuing. Earlier: Tasmania Police are searching for a female driver who allegedly evaded a breath test in Spreyton this evening. The incident occurred around 5:45pm when officers patrolling Mersey Main Road attempted to intercept a white Toyota Corolla for a random breath test. Instead of complying with police directions, the driver allegedly fled the scene, last spotted travelling along Mersey Main Road approximately five minutes after the initial attempted interception. Police unsuccessfully attempted to deploy spikes but abandoned further pursuit due to safety concerns for other road users. The vehicle, which has the registration I68XZ, has become the focus of a police appeal for public assistance. Authorities are now calling on the Spreyton community and surrounding areas to assist with the investigation by providing any relevant information. This includes dash cam footage or CCTV that may have captured the white Toyota Corolla in the area around the time of the incident. Anyone with information about the incident or the whereabouts of the vehicle is urged to contact Devonport Police on 131444, quoting ESCAD job 315-23112025.
summary: A female driver is in custody after being intercepted by police in Wesley Vale in the state’s north west . The incident occurred around 5:45pm when officers patrolling Mersey Main Road attempted to intercept a white Toyota Corolla for a random breath test . Instead of complying with police directions, the driver allegedly fled the scene . Police unsuccessfully attempted to deploy spikes but abandoned further pursuit due to safety concerns .

title: US President claims Chicago crowd called to ‘bring in Trump’ after riot with 8 shot, 1 killed
text: US President Donald Trump on Saturday claimed that Chicago residents were calling to “bring in Trump” after a wave of violence in the city. His comments followed a Friday night riot in the Chicago Loop, where at least eight teenagers were shot, one fatally, and several police officers were attacked. In a post on Truth Social, Trump wrote that there had been “massive crime and rioting in the Chicago Loop area” and said that “multiple Police Officers [were] attacked and badly injured.” He stated that “300 people” were involved in rioting and that “6 victims” had been shot, with “one critical and one DEAD.” He criticised Governor Pritzker and Chicago’s mayor, alleging they were refusing federal assistance, and added that “the people are chanting, BRING IN TRUMP!!!” The disturbance erupted after a Christmas tree lighting ceremony near State and Randolph streets at around 10 pm on Friday, according to Fox 32 Chicago. Alderman Brian Hopkins of the city’s 2nd Ward said approximately 300 juveniles were involved, using mace and stun guns against officers. He confirmed that at least one officer was hospitalised. Among those shot were six children aged 13, 14, 14, 15, 16 and 17. Less than an hour later, a 14-year-old boy was shot and later died in hospital, while an 18-year-old man was also wounded. The unrest came only days after a separate incident in which a man with a lengthy criminal record was accused of setting a woman on fire aboard a Chicago train. Lawrence Reed, 50, is charged with committing a terrorist attack or other violence against a mass transportation system. Officials said he “had no business being on the streets.” Chicago Mayor Brandon Johnson described the train assault as an “isolated incident.” Records indicate Reed has been arrested at least a dozen times since 2017, with charges including felony aggravated arson and multiple battery offenses. Despite prosecutors seeking to keep him in custody, a judge released him with an ankle monitor. Mossad claims Hamas is establishing covert networks across Europe, preparing weapons and coordinating activities. Cooperation with European agencies has disrupted plots, seized weapons, and arrested suspects. Key figures linked to Hamas in Qatar and Turkey are under investigation. Get the latest stories delivered straight to your inbox.
summary: US President Donald Trump claimed that Chicago residents were calling to “bring in Trump” after a wave of violence in the city . His comments follow a Friday night riot in the Chicago Loop, where at least eight teenagers were shot, one fatally, and several police officers were attacked . The disturbance erupted after a Christmas tree lighting ceremony near State and Randolph streets at around 10 pm .

title: Carney looks to Mandela, trade pacts to help navigate 'this moment of rupture'
text: Prime Minister Mark Carney is welcomed by Paul Mashatile, Deputy President of South Africa, as he arrives to the G20 in Johannesburg, South Africa, on Saturday, Nov. 22, 2025. THE CANADIAN PRESS/Sean Kilpatrick JOHANNESBURG - Prime Minister Mark Carney evoked the legacy of Nelson Mandela in praising efforts by fellow leaders to collaborate amid global volatility, as Canada sought more trade partners and promoted multilateralism at the G20 summit in Johannesburg. “At a time when too many countries are retreating into geopolitical blocs or the battlegrounds of protectionism, Canada believes that the G20 must remain a bridge,” Carney told reporters Sunday. He cited the legacy of former South African president Nelson Mandela, who spent 27 years in prison for his opposition to the apartheid system of racial segregation. Carney quoted Mandela as saying a societal renaissance required confronting problems that go beyond any one country. “His words spoke to a moment of rebirth in South Africa, and today they can guide how we lead the way forward, from this moment of rupture,” Carney said. He was speaking after most leaders of the G20 agreed to a joint declaration that touched on climate change and gender equality, despite U.S. President Donald Trump staging an American boycott of the Johannesburg summit. Carney saluted countries for releasing a joint document, noting it stems from “a very broad process that takes an entire year” and not just the final summit. He noted the governments who signed on represent three-quarters of global population, and two-thirds of the world’s economic output. “I look at it more from who shows up, who engages, who does the work,” Carney said. He said the American absence was “a reminder that the centre of gravity in the global economy is shifting,” with economic and political power being diffused toward multiple countries, including the Global South. “Our task is to ensure that Canada doesn’t only endure this shift, but that we prosper under it,” he said. At a formal bilateral discussion Sunday with Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, he and Carney agreed to revamp negotiations for a trade deal, which have stopped and started since 2010. Carney told reporters a comprehensive deal would have a lot more benefit than the talks toward a sectoral agreement that Canada suspended in 2023 after the assassination of a Sikh activist near Vancouver. The prime minister also co-launched a partnership Saturday with India and Australia on emerging technologies. That same day, he was part of talks between the European Union and a Pacific Rim trade bloc called the CPTPP, which could boost trade between countries trying to escape coercive practices such as American tariffs and Chinese import bans. On Sunday, Carney announced that Ottawa and South Africa agreed to launch discussions for an investment-protection pact, aimed at getting companies in both countries to work together more on clean energy and the responsible sourcing of critical minerals. He also announced that FinDev Canada would open an office in Cape Town next year to advance the agency’s work supporting private sector-led projects in emerging countries. That might help South Africa with the large infrastructure projects it has been developing so far with the help of countries like China. The news came days after South Africa’s envoy in Ottawa told The Canadian Press his country was angling toward a “wine for gas” deal that would have his country sell higher-quality wines in Canada while importing liquefied natural gas. At the summit, Carney also spoke with Angolan President João Lourenço in his capacity as chair of the African Union, about “a possibility that we could work something out” in partnering with the continental free-trade area that is taking shape, but he said he didn’t want to “overplay” the idea. “Our new government is working for Canada, to move from reliance to resilience by building a broad and dense web of new partnerships, and creating new economic opportunities that will make Canada stronger both at home and abroad,” Carney said. But Carney’s visit comes amid mounting concerns over Canada’s engagement with Africa, where he spent roughly 48 hours in a visit to South Africa and no other country on the continent. On Friday, Canadian officials in Johannesburg announced Ottawa would for the first time ever cut back its support for the Global Fund, a major health organization that tackles infectious diseases like tuberculosis and HIV. That follows a cut to foreign aid in this year’s budget, which the government insists is meant to align Ottawa with spending that took place before the COVID-19 pandemic. In March, the Liberals released an Africa strategy that seeks to go beyond viewing the continent as an aid recipient, by preparing Canadian companies to profit from Africa’s young population and booming economies. But the Trudeau Liberals released the strategy after years of delays and just days before calling an election. Ottawa allocated no new funds to the strategy, while it set aside $2.3 billion for the 2022 Indo-Pacific strategy. Canada’s special envoy for Africa, Ben Marc Diendéré, told the Senate on Oct. 30 that the strategy is hindered not just by the lack of clear funding, but because he has “had to fight to get people to say the word ‘Africa’” with the department. When asked about those comments Sunday, Carney said Africa is part of Canada’s diversification push. “Is it the first thing we worked on in terms of priorities? No,” he said. “That’s because we have a responsibility to have that highest return. Canada remains engaged with Africa.” Carney said Canada needed to focus first on deepening the strong ties Ottawa already has with economies such as Mexico, the U.K. and in Europe “to move them to the next level.” What followed was progress with high-growth Asian markets where Canada could secure “immediate results,” such as the newly signed Indonesia trade deal. “It’s still a priority; it’s one of the big continents,” he said in French. Carney also held an informal discussion Sunday with Brazilian President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, and was part of a Saturday meeting of European and Japanese counterparts who urged Washington to revise its initial peace proposal for Ukraine, which echoed much of Russia’s demands. The South African hosts highly restricted access to bilateral meetings on both days of the summit, blocking Canadian media from attending all of the engagements Carney held at the summit site. This report by The Canadian Press was first published Nov. 23, 2025.
summary: Prime Minister Mark Carney evoked the legacy of Nelson Mandela in praising efforts by fellow leaders to collaborate amid global volatility . Carney quoted Mandela as saying a societal renaissance required confronting problems that go beyond any one country . Carney was speaking after most leaders of the G20 agreed to a joint declaration that touched on climate change and gender equality .

title: Peak Trump?
text: Only the very brave or the very foolish would predict the political demise of Donald Trump. This is a US president who, over the course of his five-decade career, has escaped multiple brushes with bankruptcy, survived two impeachments in his first term, faced 91 criminal charges and been convicted on 34 of them, survived two assassination attempts, lost an election in 2020, yet was still able to return to office this year more powerful than ever. Even so, it is reasonable to ask whether, in light of recent events, we may have passed peak Trump. Of course, assuming Trump cannot find a way to circumvent the US Constitution and stand for a third term, it was always inevitable that he would see his powers wane in his final two years after next November’s midterm elections. But the heavy defeats suffered by the Republican Party in elections across America this month suggest he may be prematurely approaching lame duck status. Not only did it lose in places as different as New York, Virginia and Georgia, but the scale of defeat was much greater than polls had predicted. Investors are now betting that there is a 71 percent chance that the Republicans lose the House next year, according to Polymarket. The irony is that what turned voters against Trump was the very thing that had helped propel him back to the White House: the high cost of living. Voters blame the president for the rising cost of groceries, even as Trump claims they are falling. Some 76 percent of voters view the economy negatively, according to a poll for Fox News last week. That’s worse than the 70 percent who said the same at the end of former President Biden’s term. The same poll found that 58 percent of voters now disapprove of how Trump is doing his job, compared to 41 percent who approve. Only once has he scored lower, in October 2017 in his first term. Equally ominous for Trump are the growing splits in his MAGA movement. Last week, he was forced to back down after months of trying to block the release of the Epstein files when Republican members of Congress refused to drop their support for a bill that would force the Department of Justice to release all the information it holds on the convicted paedophile. Previously, he had called Marjorie Taylor Greene, until now one of his earliest and most loyal supporters, a “traitor” for leading the effort in Congress. The split within the Republican movement goes beyond Epstein. MAGA supporters accuse the president of spending too much time on foreign affairs rather than domestic issues. They regard his interventions in Iran, Gaza and now Venezuela as contrary to America First principles. They accuse the administration of being too welcoming to foreign labor. At the same time, traditional conservatives are outraged by the willingness of far-right MAGA influencers such as talk-show host Tucker Carlson to embrace antisemitic provocateurs such as Nick Fuentes. Meanwhile, there are other signs that Trump’s grip on all the institutional levers of power may be slipping. The Senate earlier this month voted to repeal punitive tariffs on Brazil and Canada, a sign that Trump’s enthusiasm for tariffs is not shared by all Republicans. Republicans in Indiana refused to obey Trump’s demand to gerrymander constituency boundaries to improve the party’s chances of retaining control of the House of Representatives next year. At the same time, the Supreme Court cast doubt on the legality of Trump’s use of emergency powers to impose tariffs, raising the prospect that his signature policy could be ruled unconstitutional. Trump could be in even greater trouble if the AI bubble in the stock market were to burst or deeper problems were to emerge in the vast and opaque private credit market. This risk appears less imminent in the wake of last week’s strong earnings from chipmaker Nvidia and better-than-expected employment data. But with spending on AI data centers now accounting for nearly all US growth and valuations at dotcom bubble levels, investors are rightly nervous. Given the scale of American savings invested in the stock market, a dotcom-style crash could wipe two percentage points off GDP, the International Monetary Fund has warned. The good news for Europe and the rest of the world is that a weakened Trump may be more cautious about doing anything that might undermine the US and global economy ahead of next year’s midterm elections. That may lead him to restrain his more impulsive instincts. He has already backed down over his trade war with China and last week agreed an outline trade deal with Switzerland. Other deals with countries previously in his firing line may follow. One sign that Trump recognizes his vulnerability is that he last week canceled tariffs on 200 agricultural items, an implicit admission that tariffs do push up inflation and are paid by Americans. On the other hand, even a lame duck Trump can still inflict considerable damage over the next three years. There seems little chance that he will abandon his transactional approach to foreign policy, bullying friend and foe to accept one-sided deals. What’s more, Trump is sure to go to extreme lengths to ensure the Republicans win next year’s elections, using his powers of pardon to shield those engaged in criminality, as he did with those convicted of the January 6 riots. Even if we have passed peak Trump, we are unlikely to have passed peak danger. Simon Nixon is an independent journalist and commentator on British, European and international political economy and geoeconomics.
summary: Only the very brave or the very foolish would predict the political demise of Donald Trump . But it is reasonable to ask whether, in light of recent events, we may have passed peak Trump . Heavy defeats suffered by the Republican Party in elections suggest he may be prematurely approaching lame duck status .

title: Who Is Ali Tabatabai, Hezbollah Deputy Chief That Israel Killed In Beirut Strike?
text: Israel carried out one of its most aggressive strikes inside Beirut in years, killing Hezbollah’s deputy chief and top military commander, Ali Tabatabai. The operation, conducted deep inside the Lebanese capital, was the first major Israeli strike since the November 2024 ceasefire and the first time the Israeli Air Force targeted a senior Hezbollah figure since the ceasefire. It was the fifth Israeli strike on Beirut’s southern suburbs since a ceasefire agreed in November 2024 after a year of conflict, and comes a week before Pope Leo XIV is scheduled to visit Lebanon. In the past, Israel had regularly targeted mid-level Hezbollah operatives in southern Lebanon, especially those accused of attempting to rebuild rocket-launch sites or infiltrate the border region. Ali Tabatabai was born to an Iranian father and a Lebanese mother. According to Haaretz, he was not among Hezbollah’s founders but belonged to its “second generation". He was deployed in Syria and Yemen to support allied forces in both conflict zones. Israel’s military said Tabatabai joined Hezbollah in the 1980s and went on to hold several senior roles, including in the Radwan Force, the group’s elite combat unit. The US State Department designated him a Specially Designated Global Terrorist in 2016 and announced a $5 million bounty for information on him. According to the department, Tabatabai oversaw Hezbollah’s Radwan Force operations in Syria and Yemen. The Israeli Prime Minister’s Office said he was responsible for strengthening the group’s military capabilities and overseeing its rearmament. During last year’s war, Tabatabai headed Hezbollah’s operations division and rose further in rank as several senior commanders were killed, the Israeli military added. Swipe Left For Next Video Hezbollah confirmed that senior leader Haytham Ali Tabatabai was killed in Israel’s strike on Beirut’s southern suburbs on Sunday. In a statement, the group confirmed the killing of “the great commander" Tabtabai in “a treacherous Israeli attack on the Haret Hreik area in the southern suburbs of Beirut", without specifying his position within the group.
summary: Israel carried out one of its most aggressive strikes inside Beirut in years, killing Hezbollah’s deputy chief and top military commander, Ali Tabatabai . The operation, conducted deep inside the Lebanese capital, was the first major Israeli strike since the November 2024 ceasefire . It was the fifth Israeli strike on Beirut's southern suburbs since a ceasefire agreed in November 2024 .

title: Sunbury continues on
text: Club Sunbury continued its good form with another strong performance in the Bowls Victoria weekend pennant, division 1, section 1 competition on Saturday. Sunbury was on the road against Deer Park 2 and was up to the challenge as it came away with an 86 (16)-73 (2) win. Sunbury’s David Glennon said they were pretty happy with that result. “It was a good win against one of the stronger sides that are up there,” he said. “They were just behind us in third spot. If they had won they would have leap frogged us. “There’s now a bit of a buffer between us and them.” Mark Armstrong’s rink was the standout on the day winning 27-13, while Lee Wesley’s rink won 26-15. Marc Bullows’ rink snuck home 21-20, while Desmond Cann Jnr’s rink was the only one to go down, losing 25-12. “To get 16 points at Deer Park is very good,” Glennon said. “Not many teams will get that many points playing at Deer Park. “It’s a hard place to go and get the win.” Glennon said Armstrong was one of the standouts for the side, while Lauchlin Davies had a good day in Bullows’ rink. With a few players missing, including Sophie Kurzman who is representing Victoria, there were a few different faces out there for Sunbury. Glennon said despite that they still had a fairly stable side. “We had two or three different changes,” he said. “That happens and we were still able to get the win in what I thought would be a really tough game.” Sunbury remains in second place and is 14 points behind runaway leaders Whittlesea, which are undefeated after five rounds. Sunbury’s second side in division 2 came away with a draw against Keilor to move into the top four. The club’s two division sides also got wins on weekend and are on top of the ladder. “It’s been a really good season for the club so far,” Glennon said. The top side will this Saturday face Yarraville Footscray 2. The Bulldogs sit in fifth spot, just outside the top four. Glennon said it would be another good test for the side. Meanwhile in the Ballarat Highlands Bowls Region’s Highlands division 1 competition, Kyneton and Kyneton Golf continued their good form. Golf got the win against Lancefield, 63 (14)-47 (2). Anthony Barker’s rink was the big winner for Golf, winning 23-10. Kyneton got the points against Trentham, winning 72 (14)-47 (2). It was a massive win for David James Thomas’ rink for Kyneton, winning 36-9. Kyneton sits on top of the ladder ahead of Kyneton Golf. In other matches, Diggers Rest beat Broadbord, 73 (15)-45 (1), while Romsey beat Kilmore, 78 (16)-39 (0) and Gisborne also got the perfect result, beating Woodend (80)-43 (0). After eight rounds, Kilmore and Romsey are the other teams making up the top four.
summary: Club Sunbury continued its good form in the Bowls Victoria weekend pennant, division 1, section 1 competition on Saturday . Sunbury was on the road against Deer Park 2 and was up to the challenge as it came away with an 86 (16)-73 (2) win . Mark Armstrong's rink was the standout on the day winning 27-13, while Lee Wesley’s rink won 26-15 .
