title: Mount & Blade: Warband, a highly acclaimed open world medieval game, is 75% off on Steam
text: For the first time, Black Friday deals are available on Steam, with many games at low prices. This is the case for Mount & Blade: Warband, a game taking place in a ruthless medieval world that is enjoyed by 97% of players. And it is currently available at 75% off on the platform. Mount & Blade: Warband is a game that has left its mark on thousands of players since its release in 2010, thanks to its gameplay. Indeed, you are immersed in a medieval world, on the continent of Calradia, with the aim of seizing the throne of Calradia. But for that, it will be necessary to be strategic. Five kingdoms are available, and each fights to conquer castles and villages and expand its territory. You have the possibility to choose which kingdom you want to serve by forming an alliance and fighting numerous enemies. But don’t forget, you can also betray your king to take his place. It will also be necessary to equip yourself with robust armor and powerful weapons to defeat all your opponents while conducting various strategies directly on the battlefield. Finally, lead sieges and capture numerous fiefdoms to expand your power and become the lord of Calradia. Thus, if you want to try this game, it is currently available for $4.99 on Steam until December 10. Mount & Blade: Warband is a game that is very popular among players on Steam, but also on Metacritic, where it has a rating of 78. However, there are several flaws to consider, such as the graphics. It must be said that this title was released in 2010, and some graphics have not aged well. Furthermore, while players often enjoy the fights, the lack of diversity can ruin your gaming experience. Finally, a lack of detail is also highlighted, which can give the impression that the game is sometimes empty. Disclaimer: Notebookcheck is not responsible for price changes carried out by retailers. The discounted price or deal mentioned in this item was available at the time of writing and may be subject to time restrictions and/or limited unit availability. Steam
summary: Mount & Blade: Warband is a game taking place in a ruthless medieval world that is enjoyed by 97% of players . It is currently available at 75% off on Steam until December 10 . The game is very popular among players on Steam, but also on Metacritic, where it has a rating of 78 . However, there are several flaws to consider, such as the graphics .

title: It's time to buy: 1 Australian stock that hasn't been this cheap in years
text: Image source: Getty Images You’re reading a free article with opinions that may differ from The Motley Fool’s Premium Investing Services. Become a Motley Fool member today to get instant access to our top analyst recommendations, in-depth research, investing resources, and more. Learn More If you're looking for a high-quality Australian tech stock trading well below what analysts believe it is worth, Xero Ltd (ASX: XRO) may be the opportunity hiding in plain sight. After a bruising year for ASX technology names and widespread concern about an AI-driven selloff, Xero's share price has cratered. This is a level that implies a dramatically weaker future than analysts actually expect. And according to a note out of Macquarie, the current price simply doesn't reflect Xero's long-term earnings power. In fact, the broker argues that the market is mispricing the company's US opportunity entirely. Macquarie currently has an outperform rating and a $230.30 price target on Xero. Based on its current share price, this implies potential upside of 92% for investors over the next 12 months. Macquarie's highlights that today's share price suggests that from FY 2028 Xero will miss the Rule of 40, which is a benchmark for high-performing software stocks, until FY 2033. That means the market is pricing in a dramatic slowdown in growth after FY 2-28, despite evidence to the contrary. The broker believes that its current valuation assumes Xero's core business slows to 12% annualised revenue growth beyond FY 2028 and never reaches the free-cash-flow margins achieved by its key competitor, Intuit (NASDAQ: INTU). Macquarie stresses that these assumptions are far too conservative. One of the most important points that Macquarie makes is that the US market is finally showing the same conditions that historically drove Xero's strongest growth in other regions. It notes that payment digitisation and cloud-accounting adoption are accelerating across the US, which has been a missing ingredient in past years. Xero's recent Melio acquisition gives the company a powerful distribution network and access to ~18 million small businesses via syndication partners. It said: Management are moving quickly, with deal close 2 months earlier than expected. This coincides with Trump's digitisation of payments gaining momentum. The IRS is phasing out paper refund checks from Sep 30 2025 and pushing customers to digital rails. Moreover, the GENIUS Act and the updating/adoption of FedNOW & FedRamp are pushing more customers to digital rails and digital tax. Historically, these are the two necessary preconditions for XRO to grow strongly in a market, and they are manifesting in the US now. Macquarie describes this as a "perfect storm" in Xero's favour and highlights that there is no clear number-two competitor in the US, and Intuit's growing focus on the mid-market leaves Xero's core small-business segment under-served. With the stock down sharply and Macquarie forecasting significant upside as its US strategy unfolds, Xero looks like one of the most attractive opportunities on the ASX right now. As a result, this is one Australian stock that I would happily buy more of at the current price.
summary: Xero Ltd (ASX: XRO) may be the opportunity hiding in plain sight . After a bruising year for ASX technology names and widespread concern about an AI-driven selloff, Xero's share price has cratered . Macquarie argues that the market is mispricing the company's US opportunity entirely .

title: Hornets face ‘new’ Mounties
text: Bryant Coach Quad Sanders said he knows he isn't dealing with the same Rogers team of years past. The Mounties (10-1), ranked No. 4 overall, have already had a historic season. They've won 10 games for the first time since 2006, reached the semifinals for the first time since that same year and scored the most points in a single season (574) in school history. That's what the Hornets (11-1), ranked No. 1 overall, are up against Friday night in the Class 7A semifinals at Hornet Stadium. "Those guys that we played (them) were sophomores. They're a whole lot better than they were when we played them a couple of years ago," Sanders said. "We got to be prepared for a game. I mean, it's not the Rogers that everybody once knew. It's a new Rogers. It's a new day, and I think that's what they're out to prove." Sanders is referring to their 2023 quarterfinal matchup, where Bryant defeated Rogers 56-32. Since then, Rogers has grown into one of the highest-scoring offenses in the state. Senior quarterback Jeff Regan has thrown for 1,722 yards, rushed for 1,269 yards and accounted for 45 touchdowns -- 23 rushing, 22 passing. His leading receiver is classmate Braxton Lindsey, who has committed to play linebacker at BYU next year. Lindsey has 44 catches for 759 yards and 11 touchdowns. "(Regan is) extremely fast, and he's strong," Sanders said. "It also helps to have a weapon to throw it to, like he has in Lindsey. You get a quarterback and a running back all in one, and then you get a receiver, running back and tight end all in the other. So you got about five players and two people. You just got to know where they are and be able to keep them in front of you. Because if not, one slip up goes to the house." Bryant's offensive production wasn't too dissimilar from Rogers', but it's the way the Hornets get the production that is different. The Hornets are averaging 43.6 points per game. Their two quarterbacks, senior Jeremiah Motes and junior Kyler Shelby, have a combined 2,469 yards and 26 passing touchdowns. Senior running backs Kollin Robinson and Missouri commit T.J. Hodges have a combined for 1,622 rushing yards and 26 touchdowns. Motes has taken the majority of snaps recently for the Hornets, passing for a season-high 214 yards in their win over Fayetteville in the quarterfinals, but Sanders said he'll play both without hesitation. "It's still the same," Sanders said. "I think you just got to take it drive by drive and be able to coach them up, because they don't have the experience yet. Jeremiah is just a little bit older. He caught a groove on Friday, so you really don't want to pull that groove." Sanders said there are pros and cons to having as much talent as Bryant does with multiple players per position believing they are capable of starting. but he added that overall it's a good problem to have. "I think these guys are just having fun," he said. "They're not selfish, and that's what makes a good team. Nobody's complaining, everybody's playing, doing what they're supposed to do. They all know, secretly, if I catch it, I better score, because I may not get it again." BENTON Chasing history The road to the Class 6A state championship has, more often than not, ran through Greenwood since the Bulldogs joined the classification in 2012. During that span, they've won six state championships and been to 10 title games. Since Nov. 21, 2014, the Bulldogs have won 77 consecutive home games. Benton (9-2) will need to topple a dynasty when it travels to face Greenwood (11-0) in the Class 6A semifinals Friday night. "I'm excited for the challenge," Benton quarterback Drew Davis said. "Sophomore, junior year I never got to play them. I know they're good, and you want to play the good football teams to see how you stack up against them." Greenwood is 7-2 all-time against Benton. Their last meeting also came in the 2022 semifinals, when the Bulldogs beat the Panthers 31-24. "These kids were young," Benton Coach Brad Harris said. "Some of these guys moved up and played as sophomores or freshmen against them, but they'll know how to handle that. This is not going to be a game that's going to be too big for them. They're going to be up for the challenge. "We don't have anything to lose. Nobody's going to pick us to win. We don't care." Benton has consistently been amongst the top teams in 6A over the past three seasons with this current senior class starting throughout. The one hurdle the Panthers haven't been able to get over with this group in the semifinals. Benton has lost in that round each of the past four seasons. "We want to get to that next step," Harris said. "These seniors have been to three semifinals, the first group that's done that. They're sitting at 29 wins as a team, and they got an opportunity to break that record. "It's been since 2019 since we've been to the finals. I want them to be able to taste that. I've been there, but I want these guys to be able to taste a championship run, have an opportunity to win a title." This matchup will also be a showcase of two of the state's top passing leaders, both of whom have thrown for more than 8,000 career yards. Davis has thrown for 3,119 yards, rushed for 501 yards and had a hand in a combined 54 touchdowns this season. He accounted for nine touchdowns in Benton's quarterfinal win over Mountain Home. Utah commit Kane Archer has thrown for 2,959 yards, rushed for 1,022 yards and accounted for 50 combined touchdowns. Davis said the pressure to be the senior class to get Benton back to the state championship game is there, but he's not letting that get in the way of his preparation. "Being a senior, it hits more because it's your last season, and you want to be the class to be remembered," Davis said. "I've been a part of some really good teams that made it to the semis, and we haven't been able to get over that hump. I'm just really excited for the opportunity to do it, because the talk about this year's team is we're not as good as the years past, and we're not good on defense, executing on offense. We just try to block out all the noise and focus on what we can control and what we can do." HOT SPRINGS LAKESIDE Second chance There won't be many surprises when Hot Springs Lakeside faces Little Rock Parkview in the Class 5A semifinals at War Memorial Stadium in Little Rock on Friday night. This will be the second time the 5A-South Conference foes have played this season and the fifth time in four seasons. "It's kind of like when you play Lake Hamilton," Lakeside Coach Garren Rockwell said. "They know what we're going to do, and we know what they're going to do. It ain't no schematic (change), too many adjustments. Let's get out here and play football. "It's still this smash-mouth football. They want to run the ball, play-action pass off of it. We want to try to establish the run and get one-on-one matchups with our receivers on their DBs. And it's the same thing they want to do against us." Lakeside (9-3) has never beaten Parkview (9-3), but its closest loss came on Oct. 31, when the three-time defending state champion Patriots won 24-22. Rockwell said he's hoping a second crack at them is what the Rams need to advance to the state championship game for the first time since 1975. "It's big time for the familiarity of it," Rockwell said. "These first two playoff games, we had never played Searcy before, ever, like in program history, and same thing with Greenbrier. And so you don't know what to expect, but we know what to expect at Parkview. It's going to be a good, physical game. Both sides got something to prove, and it should be a good contest." Lakeside lost back-to-back games against Parkview and crosstown rival Hot Springs to end the regular season, dropping it to a No. 3 seed. After a convincing win over Searcy in the first round, Lakeside beat 5A-West champion Greenbrier, which was previously undefeated, 24-21 last week to advance to this game. The Patriots are looking for their fourth straight state title game despite finishing second in the conference for the first time since 2021. Parkview defeated Maumelle by three touchdowns in the first round before scoring a late touchdown in the quarterfinals to defeat Harrison 21-17. Support journalism that covers the topics that matter most to you. Donate today to preserve the quality and integrity of local journalism. [email protected] Sam Lane covers Arkansas high school sports, with an emphasis on football, and University of Central Arkansas athletics. He has been with the Arkansas Democrat-Gazette since 2022.
summary: Rogers is ranked No. 4 overall in Class 7A . The Mounties have won 10 games for the first time since 2006 . They've won the most points in a single season in school history . The Hornets are averaging 43.6 points per game .

title: Cops nab 16-year-old over assault of student at Sungai Petani school dormitory
text: SUNGAI PETANI: A 16-year-old student has been remanded for three days to assist in the investigation of an assault case involving a Form Four student who was allegedly beaten unconscious at a school dormitory here early Monday (Nov 24) morning. The victim was found unconscious in a school toilet by his teacher before being sent to Sultan Abdul Halim Hospital for treatment. The boy’s mother was informed of the incident by the school at 9.05am, with bruising observed on her son’s body. It is learnt the victim was assaulted at around 12.10am, purportedly after allegedly badmouthing a friend of one of the suspects. Kuala Muda OCPD Asst Comm Hanyan Ramlan said preliminary investigations indicated that a student, angered by the victim’s alleged humiliation of his friend, invited three other students to confront the victim. Initially, four students aged between 16 and 17 were detained to assist in the investigation. However, only one, the Form Four student, was remanded for three days, while the other three were released by the Sungai Petani Court on Thursday (Nov 27). ACP Hanyan said this was the first such case at the dormitory, and there were no closed-circuit television (CCTV) recordings at the scene. The case is being investigated under Section 507 of the Penal Code. Thank you for your report!
summary: A 16-year-old student has been remanded for three days to assist in the investigation of an assault case involving a Form Four student who was allegedly beaten unconscious at a school dormitory here early Monday (Nov 24) morning . The victim was found unconscious in a school toilet by his teacher before being sent to Sultan Abdul Halim Hospital for treatment .

title: Coleman ready to see what Warriors are made of
text: It's still early in season, but Little Rock Hall boys basketball Coach Jon Coleman indicated that he's liked what he's seen out of his team. He may like them even more if the Warriors are able to bring home a title from one of the nation's more renown Thanksgiving tournaments. The 28th annual Rumble on the Ridge is set to begin Thursday at Dwight Lofton Mustang Arena in Forrest City with a four-game slate in a stacked boys division that'll feature six in-state teams. As has been the case since 2023, there will be a four-team girls division that will tip off Friday. The event is one of several taking place over the holiday weekend across the state. Others include the James Banks Classic in Marianna, the S.T.R.O.N.G. Showcase in Jacksonville and the Battle in the Rock at Little Rock Parkview to name a few. But Coleman has an affinity for the Rumble on the Ridge. His teams have played in the showcase seven other times, and he's always used it as a barometer to see where his Warriors stand. He's again expecting to get a gauge about his group's standing during this year's three-day event, starting with first-round foe Memphis Southwind. "I'll say they're a familiar opponent," Coleman said. "Over the years, we've hooked up with them in some very good games. I don't think we've played since 2017 or 2018, but it'll be a good opponent for us. "I think they're ranked like fifth or sixth in Tennessee so anytime you can play a good basketball team early, it can't do anything but aid the growth of our team." Progress is what Coleman said he has been searching for with his team. Hall (3-2), which is coming off a 60-31 victory over Little Rock Catholic on Tuesday, has a wealth of experience back from last year's team that finished 19-7. A pair of all-state seniors in University of Arkansas at Little Rock commit Micah Moore, a 5-10 guard, and Landen Hill, a 6-4 small forward, are back. The two combined for 31 points, with Moore tallying a game-high 20, in the Warriors' 29-point win over the Rockets. Coleman mentioned that Hill, who's essentially a four-year starter, and Moore, who suffered a hand injury last season before returning, have played well, along with senior Shaah Rahmaan, another veteran who's logged plenty of minutes as a starter . Hall also got a boost when Jace Sullivan, a 6-5 guard, transferred in from Conway during the offseason. However, one of the biggest pluses the Warriors have going for them is the return of Tristan Jahnke. The 6-9 forward tore an ACL early last season but is starting to ramp things up after getting cleared to play. "He's healthy," Coleman said of his senior big man. "He hadn't played in over a year and really just got released probably a couple of days before the season kicked off to basically start scrimmaging and having contact. So it's good to have him back in the mix. "And I keep telling the guys, at this point last year we probably look exactly like we look now. Tristan and Micah both got hurt, but the guys really started playing together after that. When Micah came back, it was an even more cohesive group with him in there. So we're trying to get back to that point where we're playing for each other like we were then." Coleman has tested his Warriors already this season. Hall has played last year's Class 5A state finalists, Maumelle and Benton, as well as Farmington, which reached the playoffs last season and is one of the favorites to make a deep postseason push next March. Hall went 1-2 in those games, but the defeats to reigning champion Benton (53-45) and Farmington (46-35) were competitive throughout. "Not taking anything away from those teams because they're really good, but we had our chances," Coleman said. "I think a more cohesive unit may have a made a big difference. I tell the guys, we've got to be able to do the small things if we're going to win those close games." Those details are what Coleman said he is hoping the Warriors cling to at the Rumble on the Ridge. They're guaranteed to play three games, and each figures to test Hall in a multitude of ways. But that's just how its long-time coach likes it. "We're going to Forrest City to look for some more chemistry to get better," Coleman said. "The Rumble used to be known as one of the better Thanksgiving tournaments, and I think they're moving back in that direction. There's some really solid teams this year, including a really good North Little Rock group, Hot Springs and some others. "So I like the feel of it, and I really like the way (organizers) run the tournament. That's why any time we get a chance to go, that's one of the places we head to." [email protected] Erick Taylor is the Arkansas Democrat-Gazette's high school sports coordinator and lead reporter for Division II, Division III and NAIA football. He has been involved in sports journalism for 25 years.
summary: The 28th annual Rumble on the Ridge is set to begin Thursday at Dwight Lofton Mustang Arena in Forrest City . Little Rock Hall boys basketball Coach Jon Coleman says he's liked what he's seen out of his team . He's again expecting to get a gauge about his group's standing during the tournament .

title: Dear Abby: After 20 years of marriage couple finally plans a vacation alone, until husband totally messes it up
text: DEAR ABBY: My husband and I married 20 years ago. We have a blended family of eight kids, but it’s just us now. Our kids are scattered across the country. Over all these 20 years, we have never taken a vacation just for us. We have always visited family. Now, after scrimping, saving and planning, our dream trip is finally happening. We are visiting Disneyland! Problem is, our youngest just relocated to L.A. I bought tickets, scheduled tours and reserved meals for just the two of us. But my husband has included our son in everything now -- all park visits, dinners, etc. Don’t get me wrong -- I love my kids, but this was supposed to be “our” time. I agreed to one dinner with our son, but other than that, we are on our own. My husband wants to include him in everything because he lives close by. Now my husband says he doesn’t want to go at all. He insists that our son partake in everything we do, but I want this trip to be about us. We deserve this! How do I convince him that we need this trip? -- DISAPPOINTED IN OHIO DEAR DISAPPOINTED: You shouldn’t have to convince your husband to follow through on your dream vacation. He should have consulted you before inviting your son and telling him he will be included in everything. You wrote that you scrimped and saved for years to afford this vacation. How does he intend to pay for all those extra expenses for a third person? If your husband doesn’t want an experience “just for the two of you,” allow me to suggest it may be time to schedule something just for yourself. You have earned it. DEAR ABBY: I was engaged to my husband for three years before we got married. A little more than a year ago, he was told that he had two years to live. Six months later, we celebrated our 25th wedding anniversary, and 10 days after that, he passed away. I have met a man who is two years younger than I am who makes me laugh again. I feel like a schoolgirl when I’m around him. He wants to be a roommate, live with me and sleep upstairs. I sleep downstairs, but I don’t know if I should let him or not. Advice? -- FEELING A BIT SCARED IN INDIANA DEAR FEELING: Would this man be paying you rent and buying food, or would you be picking up the tab? If all he wants is to be your platonic roommate, but you are physically attracted to him, I recommend against proceeding with the arrangement. You would find it increasingly painful and frustrating, and when you finally had had enough pain and frustration, you might have to hire an attorney to help you get him out. What seems attractive now could be a huge pain in the posterior, and I guarantee it wouldn’t leave you laughing. Keep things as they are until the relationship becomes more defined. Dear Abby is written by Abigail Van Buren, also known as Jeanne Phillips, and was founded by her mother, Pauline Phillips. Contact Dear Abby at or P.O. Box 69440, Los Angeles, CA 90069. Jeanne Phillips, also known as Abigail Van Buren, has written the advice column “Dear Abby” since 2000, responding knowledgeably with the wit and compassion that earns her the loyalty of millions of fans. She’s... more
summary: After scrimping, saving and planning, our dream trip is finally happening . But my husband has included our son in everything now -- all park visits, dinners, etc. Now my husband says he doesn't want to go at all . How do I convince him that we need this trip?

title: Residents mull new fire district in canyon
text: LENORE — Volunteer firefighters are kicking around the idea of starting a new rural fire district to cover an area north of the Clearwater River from east of Arrow Junction to just west of Lenore. The notion was inspiration born of a touch of desperation. This winter, from Dec. 1 to March 1, fire coverage will diminish as two of three fire engines have to be moved out of a county-owned, insulated pole-building that the Big Canyon Fire District (BCFD) leases and shares with Nez Perce County Road and Bridge Department in Lenore. After a September meeting between three Nez Perce County commissioners and BCFD leaders, the county followed up with an Oct. 16 email telling BCFD to vacate half of the structure. The road department said it needs the space to store a de-icer truck and de-icing chemicals. “That’s our only option for a shop because of the restrictions on Lenore Bridge,” said NPC Road Director Roy Hill. Until now, the fire district used the whole building despite an agreement with the county that entitled them to half, Hill said. But in 2023, the Idaho Transportation Department reduced the truck weights allowed on the steel, wood and concrete Lenore Bridge, which was built in 1935. Now that the Sunnyside Bench Road is paved from Orofino to Lenore, the county needs the too-heavy deicer truck parked on the north side of the river. Hill said bags of deicer need to be stored inside or they absorb moisture and become unusable bricks. BCFD fire leaders have a similar problem: fire engines need to be parked inside. Unfortunately, the volunteers were unable to find alternative space, said BCFD Fire Chief Randy Maas. So, BCFD is moving two fire trucks out and leaving only one. The Sunnyside Volunteer Fire District will help pick up the slack in coverage over the winter. In the meantime, Craig Selby, a BCFD volunteer firefighter since 2023, decided it may be time to look into starting a new fire district. Some people may not be able to get insurance without a fire district, he said. And, a homeowner who helps pay for a fire district may see significant savings with reduced home insurance costs. Selby, Maas, and BCFD Commissioner Bruce Lang were all at an informational meeting held Nov. 11 at the Lenore Community Center where they discussed the new fire district idea. Early discussions with community members have been met with general support and resulted in two offers of donated land to build a new shop. By way of comparison, the BCFD runs on a $30,000 annual budget, Lang said. He also noted that the new district would have no paid positions, despite rumors to the contrary. While locals mull over the new fire district, the county road department will return the space to the BCFD in Lenore next spring. The county has pledged to build another shed for its equipment in the summer. In an email to the Lewiston Tribune, NPC Commissioner Joe Gish wrote: “NPC also agreed to build a new heated shop on the Lenore lot’s lower flat next summer for storing NPC Road Department equipment and give BCFD a long term lease of the existing Lenore Shop for its sole use. This solution will eliminate any future conflicts. NPC has begun the planning for the new shop and also believes we have identified a funding source.” As for increased local needs and the competition for space, mostly it’s connected to the influx of people building homes in the fire-prone landscape along the Clearwater River. Roy Hill estimates that the population along the Clearwater has at least quadrupled in the past decade. Lang says some folks have moved in from out of state with little practical knowledge of the area’s fire risk. “A lot of people have moved here and don’t really know what they’re in for,” Lang said. If the past several years are any indicator, the whole community is in for hot, dry summers that make homeowners appreciate volunteer fire departments. The Clearwater Canyon corridor has seen devastating fires in recent years. The Gwen Fire in 2024 burned more than 118 structures — which included 25 homes — and more than 28,800 acres. In 2021, the Bedrock Fire near Lenore burned 11,000 acres, taking with it three homes and a dozen other structures. Ferguson can be reached at dferguson@lmtribune.com.
summary: Nez Perce County Road and Bridge Department in Lenore is moving two of three fire engines out of a county-owned pole-building . Road department said it needs the space to store a de-icer truck and de-icing chemicals . The Sunnyside Volunteer Fire District will pick up the slack in coverage over the winter .

title: They remain silent on feminicide
text: İlayda KayaThe decision to impose life imprisonment for the crime of femicide (the gender-based killing of women) in Italy was one of the biggest steps taken globally in the fight against violence against women. While countries such as Argentina, Peru and Malta have for years defined female murders as a separate crime and imposed severe penalties, in Turkey ‘killing because she is a woman’ is still not recognised as a specific category of crime. In female murder cases, the judicial process is conducted without regard to gender, obscuring the gender dimension. With this judicial process, perpetrators receive low sentences due to provocation and good behaviour reductions. Women are reacting to Turkey's failure to recognise “femicide” as a specific crime and to take comprehensive steps to strengthen deterrence against the daily increase in femicides.DETERRENT PUNISHMENT IS ESSENTIALCanan Güllü, President of the Federation of Women's Associations of Turkey, said the following about the decision: "There is still no such definition in Turkey regarding the murder of women. Murders are removed from the gender-based category and classified as “intentional killing”.Following the murders of women in Italy, they recognised the danger and took a decision to prevent it by classifying it as gender-based murder through femicide. The situation in Turkey is worse; murders of women are increasing exponentially, especially after the Istanbul Convention was repealed. Furthermore, the perception of impunity is very widespread in the judicial processes in Turkey. We also see judges saying, “I take a human-centred approach”. In Italy, these important steps and the parliamentary decisions taken are undermining the perpetrators. The impunity in our country, however, encourages the perpetrators. We must follow this path too. When a woman is murdered, the perpetrator should be given a life sentence."HEAVY PENALTIES ARE IMPOSEDIn recent years various countries have introduced legal measures to combat femicides. They have defined femicide as a separate offence and aimed to prevent reduced sentences for women’s murders. Some recent examples are:• ARGENTINA: In 2012 femicide was defined as “aggravated murder” and punishable by life imprisonment. In 2024 the country recorded 295 femicide cases which meant a woman was killed every 30 hours. The situation worsened in 2025. In the first four months 96 women’s murders were reported with the highest numbers in Buenos Aires, Santa Fe and Córdoba.• PERU: The National Institute of Statistics and Informatics (INEI) reported 146 femicide cases in 2023. Between 2015 and 2023 a total of 1,191 cases were recorded with the highest annual number in 2018 at 150. Femicide is recognised as an independent offence and carries a minimum sentence of 20 years. In severe cases the sentence is aggravated life imprisonment.• MALTA: Femicide was added as a separate aggravating factor in the criminal code in June 2022. Courts are expected to impose the heaviest penalty in gender-based killings of women and life imprisonment became the standard sanction. The aim is to prevent sentence reductions for these crimes.• NORTH MACEDONIA: Amendments to the criminal code in February 2023 added a new paragraph defining the killing of a woman as an act of gender-based violence. It states “Another offence of ending the life of a woman or girl under 18 while committing gender-based violence”.• CROATIA: In 2023 femicide began to be defined as a specific offence. Penalties are harsher especially when the perpetrator is a partner or former partner.• BOLIVIA: Under a law adopted in 2013 femicide is categorised as a specific offence. The maximum penalty is up to 30 years in prison with no reductions applied.UNJUST PROVOCATION REDUCTIONS ARE UNACCEPTABLEIn Italy the right-wing coalition government’s bill imposing heavy penalties such as life imprisonment for women’s murders was unanimously approved in the lower house, the Chamber of Deputies, and became law. Reports stated that between 1 January and 20 October 2025, 85 women were killed in the country. In Turkey 317 women were killed in the first ten months of 2025. Sentence reductions were applied to men who murdered women. Some examples are:• 13.08.25 – In İzmir Serkan Dindar appeared before the court for killing Ceyda Yüksel after she rejected his sexual advance. He was tried on the charge of “premeditated murder” with a request for 24 years in prison. An “unjust provocation reduction” was applied and the sentence was lowered to 18 years.• 18.02.25 – In Diyarbakır Özcan Yıldız, who murdered Rozerin Yıldız while they were in the process of divorcing, received an “unjust provocation” reduction. The court sentenced him to 19 years 2 months.POLICE OFFICER KILLED THE WOMANIn Kayseri police officer S.U. killed his mother-in-law M.M. The incident happened around 13.00 yesterday in the Melikgazi district. At a vineyard house an argument broke out between 35-year-old S.U. and his 60-year-old mother-in-law M.M. over inheritance. S.U. shot M.M. with a pistol then shot himself with the same weapon. Police and medical teams were sent to the scene upon a report. S.U., who was seriously injured, was taken to hospital after first aid by medical teams. An investigation was launched into the incident.Note: This article is translated from the original article titled Cinskırıma karşı çıt çıkarmıyorlar, published in BirGün newspaper on November 27, 2025. While countries such as Argentina, Peru and Malta have for years defined female murders as a separate crime and imposed severe penalties, in Turkey ‘killing because she is a woman’ is still not recognised as a specific category of crime. In female murder cases, the judicial process is conducted without regard to gender, obscuring the gender dimension. With this judicial process, perpetrators receive low sentences due to provocation and good behaviour reductions. In severe cases the sentence is aggravated life imprisonment.• MALTA: Femicide was added as a separate aggravating factor in the criminal code in June 2022. Courts are expected to impose the heaviest penalty in gender-based killings of women and life imprisonment became the standard sanction. The aim is to prevent sentence reductions for these crimes.• NORTH MACEDONIA: Amendments to the criminal code in February 2023 added a new paragraph defining the killing of a woman as an act of gender-based violence. It states “Another offence of ending the life of a woman or girl under 18 while committing gender-based violence”.• CROATIA: In 2023 femicide began to be defined as a specific offence. Penalties are harsher especially when the perpetrator is a partner or former partner.• BOLIVIA: Under a law adopted in 2013 femicide is categorised as a specific offence. The maximum penalty is up to 30 years in prison with no reductions applied.UNJUST PROVOCATION REDUCTIONS ARE UNACCEPTABLEIn Italy the right-wing coalition government’s bill imposing heavy penalties such as life imprisonment for women’s murders was unanimously approved in the lower house, the Chamber of Deputies, and became law. He was tried on the charge of “premeditated murder” with a request for 24 years in prison. An “unjust provocation reduction” was applied and the sentence was lowered to 18 years.• 18.02.25 – In Diyarbakır Özcan Yıldız, who murdered Rozerin Yıldız while they were in the process of divorcing, received an “unjust provocation” reduction. The court sentenced him to 19 years 2 months.POLICE OFFICER KILLED THE WOMANIn Kayseri police officer S.U. killed his mother-in-law M.M. The incident happened around 13.00 yesterday in the Melikgazi district. At a vineyard house an argument broke out between 35-year-old S.U. and his 60-year-old mother-in-law M.M. over inheritance. S.U. shot M.M. with a pistol then shot himself with the same weapon. Police and medical teams were sent to the scene upon a report. S.U., who was seriously injured, was taken to hospital after first aid by medical teams. An investigation was launched into the incident.Note: This article is translated from the original article titled Cinskırıma karşı çıt çıkarmıyorlar, published in BirGün newspaper on November 27, 2025.
