title: Fabrizio Romano: Mohamed Salah Could Miss Liverpool vs Inter Milan After Outburst
text: Mohamed Salah could be out of Liverpool’s squad to face Inter Milan in the Champions League following his explosive public outburst on Saturday, senior GIVEMESPORT correspondent Fabrizio Romano has revealed. The Egypt international made headlines following Liverpool’s 3-3 draw with Leeds, as he accused the club of 'throwing him under the bus' after being dropped to the bench for a third Premier League game in a row. Salah, who also revealed that his relationship with head coach Arne Slot is broken, is believed to have 'shocked' those internally at the club with his comments, with discussions ongoing over the Egyptian’s status ahead of Tuesday’s clash with Inter. Slot is due to speak to the press today ahead of Liverpool’s return to Champions League action, as the Reds look to bounce back following their 4-1 home loss to PSV last time out. Romano, writing on X, revealed that Salah could miss Liverpool’s trip to Inter Milan following his explosive post-match comments on Saturday, with a final verdict on the Egypt international expected today. Salah has played just 45 minutes across Liverpool’s last three Premier League games, having been brought off the bench during their 1-1 home draw with Sunderland last week. The Egyptian forward has struggled for form this season, scoring four times and providing two assists in 13 Premier League appearances. He has added another two goal involvements in five Champions League games, with Liverpool collecting nine points during that run. Salah’s public outburst following Liverpool’s 3-3 draw at Leeds is unlikely to have any negative impact on Slot’s future as manager. According to reports, Liverpool remain behind the Dutch tactician despite their disappointing run of form, winning just twice in their last 10 Premier League games. During that stretch, the Reds have collected only eight points from a possible 30 and lost ground to league leaders Arsenal, who are 10 points ahead. Sign up to our free newsletter for daily updates from Fabrizio Romano and Ben Jacobs.
summary: Mohamed Salah could miss Liverpool's trip to Inter Milan in the Champions League . Egypt international made headlines following Liverpool’s 3-3 draw with Leeds on Saturday . Salah accused the club of 'throwing him under the bus' after being dropped to the bench for a third Premier League game in a row . The Egypt international also revealed that his relationship with head coach Arne Slot is broken .

title: Leonardo DiCaprio was spotted cheering for Travis Kelce during the Chiefs vs. Texans game while watching from Taylor Swift’s suite
text: Arati spent six years studying medicine and three years in management, but her passion for writing was too strong to ignore. Having been a vice-captain for her college’s cricket team all four years, she was no stranger to an NFL quarterback’s competitive spirit. She creates compelling football stories that leave a mark on the readers’ hearts, not just their minds. Every morning, she begins her day by flipping through the pages of the TOI sports section to see who scored how much. In the evenings, she indulges in solving intriguing mysteries in the elite world of Olivia Benson from Law & Order: SVU. The sea of Mumbai brings her a sense of tranquility, and nothing soothes her soul quite like Kishore Kumar's melodies.Read More
summary: Arati spent six years studying medicine and three years in management . She was vice-captain for her college’s cricket team all four years . In the evenings, she indulges in solving intriguing mysteries in the elite world of Law & Order: SVU .

title: Jamaica’s Tourism Industry now Rebounds with Sandals Dunn’s River Resort’s Grand Reopening
text: Published on December 8, 2025 In a highly anticipated event for both locals and international travelers, Sandals Dunn’s River Resort in Ocho Rios, Jamaica, has officially reopened its doors, signaling a major milestone in the island’s tourism recovery efforts for 2025. After several weeks of preparation and tight collaboration between local communities, tourism partners, and the resort team, the revival of one of Jamaica’s most beloved all-inclusive resorts marks a turning point in the nation’s tourism industry, which was significantly impacted by the effects of Hurricane Melissa.The reopening of Sandals Dunn’s River Resort is not just a rejuvenation of a luxury hospitality icon, but also a key moment in Jamaica’s post-disaster tourism resurgence. Located along the beautiful North Coast of the island, the resort’s return marks the beginning of a broader tourism comeback that has been carefully planned for the past several months.Advertisement The Rebirth of Sandals Dunn’s River ResortSandals Dunn’s River Resort has long been one of Jamaica’s top all-inclusive destinations, offering travelers access to the pristine beaches of Ocho Rios, luxurious accommodations, and world-class amenities. The resort is particularly famous for its proximity to the Dunn’s River Falls, one of Jamaica’s most iconic natural attractions, drawing visitors from around the globe who want to experience the exhilarating climb and stunning beauty of the waterfalls.Following the disruptions caused by Hurricane Melissa in late 2024, which impacted several parts of the Caribbean, including Jamaica, the resort had to temporarily close for repairs and upgrades. During its closure, Sandals worked with local communities and tourism officials to ensure that the reopening would be an event that could showcase both the resilience of the resort and the island’s commitment to sustainable tourism.After extensive refurbishments and upgrades, including enhanced guest rooms, new dining options, and a revitalized wellness center, the resort has now returned to its full capacity, offering visitors an elevated experience. The reopening is seen as a direct response to the challenges faced by the island’s tourism sector, and it aims to bring in new visitors while reinvigorating the local economy.A Boost for Ocho Rios and Jamaica’s Tourism SectorThe reopening of Sandals Dunn’s River Resort holds special significance for the town of Ocho Rios, one of Jamaica’s most visited destinations. Ocho Rios is a popular stop for cruise ships, with visitors often looking for a mix of relaxation, adventure, and cultural experiences. The reopening of the resort will not only provide luxury accommodations for tourists, but also bring significant economic benefits to the local community through job creation and increased business for local vendors and attractions.Advertisement For Jamaica, the resort’s revival represents a wider effort to rebuild the tourism industry, which plays a central role in the nation’s economy. Tourism contributes heavily to employment, government revenue, and the country’s global reputation as a premier travel destination. In recent months, Jamaica has seen steady growth in visitor numbers, but the reopening of Sandals Dunn’s River Resort represents a symbolic beginning for the island’s complete tourism recovery.Attractions and Amenities at Sandals Dunn’s River ResortOne of the most attractive aspects of Sandals Dunn’s River Resort is its all-inclusive nature, which provides guests with a seamless and hassle-free vacation experience. The resort offers a range of accommodations from luxurious suites with ocean views to more secluded, intimate bungalows. The property also features several gourmet dining options, including both international and Caribbean-inspired cuisine, as well as bars, a wellness center, and a variety of recreational activities.For those seeking adventure, the resort offers direct access to Dunn’s River Falls, where guests can climb the famous cascading waters and explore the lush surroundings. In addition to this natural wonder, Ocho Rios offers a wealth of activities, including horseback riding along the beach, zip-lining, and trips to nearby attractions such as Mystic Mountain, which features an exciting chairlift ride and bobsledding experience.Visitors can also enjoy a wide range of water activities like snorkeling, kayaking, and scuba diving, as well as take part in daily entertainment, live performances, and cultural events. For those looking to relax and unwind, the resort’s tranquil pools, spa services, and beach access provide a perfect environment for rejuvenation.The Importance of Sustainable TourismAs Jamaica continues its post-Melissa tourism recovery, there is a growing focus on sustainable tourism practices. Sandals Resorts has long been a leader in promoting environmental responsibility, and the reopening of Dunn’s River Resort further emphasizes this commitment. The resort’s efforts include using eco-friendly building materials, implementing water conservation practices, and sourcing food locally to support Jamaican farmers and producers.In addition to its environmental initiatives, the resort continues to prioritize cultural sustainability, offering visitors opportunities to engage with local communities and learn about Jamaican heritage. By supporting local artisans, performers, and vendors, Sandals helps to ensure that the benefits of tourism are shared more widely across the island.Looking Ahead: Jamaica’s Post-Pandemic and Post-Storm Tourism RevivalThe reopening of Sandals Dunn’s River Resort is only one of several initiatives that aim to bring tourists back to Jamaica. With ongoing efforts to improve infrastructure, increase flights to the island, and diversify its tourism offerings, Jamaica is well-positioned to continue attracting international visitors in 2025 and beyond. In addition, other resorts and local attractions are also ramping up their operations to welcome back travelers who are seeking safe, fun, and relaxing experiences.Tourism authorities in Jamaica have stressed the importance of collaborating with both the private and public sectors to ensure that the island’s tourism industry remains resilient and competitive in a rapidly changing global market. The opening of Sandals Dunn’s River is just the beginning of the island’s journey back to its status as a leading Caribbean destination.Conclusion: A New Chapter for Jamaica’s TourismThe official reopening of Sandals Dunn’s River Resort in Ocho Rios marks a significant chapter in Jamaica’s recovery journey following the impact of Hurricane Melissa. This milestone not only highlights the resilience of the Jamaican tourism industry but also sets the stage for future growth. With a renewed focus on sustainability, community engagement, and world-class hospitality, the resort’s return is poised to boost the island’s tourism sector and attract visitors seeking a vibrant and unforgettable vacation experience.Advertisement Share On:Tags: all-inclusive Jamaica resorts, jamaica resorts, Jamaica tourism comeback, Ocho Rios resort, Ocho Rios tourism, post-Melissa tourism recovery, Sandals Dunn’s River Resort reopening, Sandals resorts 2025, Sandals resorts JamaicaSubscribe to our NewslettersFollow Travel And Tour World in Google News The reopening of Sandals Dunn’s River Resort is not just a rejuvenation of a luxury hospitality icon, but also a key moment in Jamaica’s post-disaster tourism resurgence. For those looking to relax and unwind, the resort’s tranquil pools, spa services, and beach access provide a perfect environment for rejuvenation.The Importance of Sustainable TourismAs Jamaica continues its post-Melissa tourism recovery, there is a growing focus on sustainable tourism practices. Sandals Resorts has long been a leader in promoting environmental responsibility, and the reopening of Dunn’s River Resort further emphasizes this commitment. In addition, other resorts and local attractions are also ramping up their operations to welcome back travelers who are seeking safe, fun, and relaxing experiences.Tourism authorities in Jamaica have stressed the importance of collaborating with both the private and public sectors to ensure that the island’s tourism industry remains resilient and competitive in a rapidly changing global market. title: Freeport-McMoRan Inc. Sued for Securities Law Violations – Investors Should Contact The Gross Law Firm Before January 12, 2026 to Discuss Your Rights – FCX
text: NEW YORK, Dec. 08, 2025 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- The Gross Law Firm issues the following notice to shareholders of Freeport-McMoRan Inc. (NYSE: FCX). Shareholders who purchased shares of FCX during the class period listed are encouraged to contact the firm regarding possible lead plaintiff appointment. Appointment as lead plaintiff is not required to partake in any recovery. CONTACT US HERE: CLASS PERIOD: February 15, 2022 to September 24, 2025 ALLEGATIONS: The complaint alleges that during the class period, Defendants issued materially false and/or misleading statements and/or failed to disclose that: (1) Freeport did not adequately ensure safety at the Grasberg Block Cave mine in Indonesia; (2) the lack of proper safety precautions constituted a heightened risk that could foreseeably lead to the death of Freeport’s workers; (3) this constituted an undisclosed heightened risk of regulatory, litigation, and reputational risk; and (4) as a result, defendants’ statements about Freeport-MoMoRan’s business, operations, and prospects were materially false and misleading and/or lacked a reasonable basis at all relevant times. DEADLINE: January 12, 2026 Shareholders should not delay in registering for this class action. Register your information here: NEXT STEPS FOR SHAREHOLDERS: Once you register as a shareholder who purchased shares of FCX during the timeframe listed above, you will be enrolled in a portfolio monitoring software to provide you with status updates throughout the lifecycle of the case. The deadline to seek to be a lead plaintiff is January 12, 2026. There is no cost or obligation to you to participate in this case. WHY GROSS LAW FIRM? The Gross Law Firm is a nationally recognized class action law firm, and our mission is to protect the rights of all investors who have suffered as a result of deceit, fraud, and illegal business practices. The Gross Law Firm is committed to ensuring that companies adhere to responsible business practices and engage in good corporate citizenship. The firm seeks recovery on behalf of investors who incurred losses when false and/or misleading statements or the omission of material information by a company lead to artificial inflation of the company's stock. Attorney advertising. Prior results do not guarantee similar outcomes. CONTACT:The Gross Law Firm15 West 38th Street, 12th floorNew York, NY, 10018Email: dg@securitiesclasslaw.com Phone: (646) 453-8903
summary: The Gross Law Firm issues notice to shareholders of Freeport-McMoRan Inc. (NYSE: FCX) Shareholders who purchased shares of FCX during the class period listed are encouraged to contact the firm regarding possible lead plaintiff appointment . There is no cost or obligation to you to participate in this case .

title: Children's Auction still seeking donations of items for bid
text: BELMONT — Right up to the 11th hour before the 44th Greater Lakes Region Children’s Auction starts, donations were pouring in on Monday, as volunteers and board members prepared for the annual event that has raised more than $9.2 million to help local children since it began. Greg Lafoe, an employee for Watermark Marine Supply Store, pushed a shopping cart with boxes of inflatable kayaks and towable tubes through the entry of the auction headquarters on Monday afternoon. Wearing a smile, knowing the items will surely make someone happy and also provide funds for children's causes, Lafoe said he loves to be able to give back to his community. “Anything to help out people in need,” Lafoe said. A short time after, auction Chair Doug Morissette walked into the headquarters with an envelope of cash donations in his hand, much to the delight of Executive Director Jenn Kelley. “There are never enough donations, because the need really just keeps growing year after year,” Kelley said. “The more items we get, the more money we make, and the more money we give. While we are so grateful for the amount of items we have right now, we are always asking for more.” The day before the auction is one of both anticipation and excitement for all who take part. This year is different, however, as it is the first event without Warren Bailey, the founder and the driving force behind the auction. While he is not there in a physical form — he died in August — Kelley said his spirit will always live on and continue to inspire those involved. “We’ve got so many volunteers helping and people coming in to give donations, dropping off items,” Kelley said. “This year is all in celebration of Warren Bailey, who sadly passed this summer. I am so incredibly grateful that he was the visionary that he was to start this. The community relies on the money we raise.” Morissette said on Monday the group had about 1,500 items to auction off so far, and about 2,800 are needed. He is encouraging people to keep bringing items in. They can be dropped off all week long. “People were dropping off all weekend,” he said. “We had a lot of items dropped off Saturday and Sunday, with just over 500 dropped. That is fantastic. It is amazing to see the community do this for such a great cause.” Kelley said this is an “incredibly giving and thoughtful community," and she could not be more excited for this week’s push to raise hundreds of thousands of dollars for children in the Lakes Region. While Laconia is at the heart of the distribution, it spans far and wide, going all the way west to Andover, north to Sandwich, east to Ossipee, and south to Pittsfield. Lakes Region Public Access and Lakes 101.5 FM are handling the brunt of the broadcasting for the week-long event, and representatives of both were making sure all was getting set up and ready to go. Grace McNamara, station manager for LRPA, spent Monday making sure the audio and video feeds were working properly, using past experience to ensure a seamless production. She and her husband Marc, who was also volunteering at the auction, were sorting through headsets and making sure all the gear was in place. “Today’s our last day to double check the audio and video, and then tomorrow morning we go live over broadcast and streaming,” said McNamara, who is in her 11th year as the station manager. “I’m the fourth station manager with the auction, and I know I speak for everyone when I say it is an honor to work with so many volunteers in the community.” McNamara said it is truly a giant family that puts it all together, and every person has a role in making it work. Lakes FM owner Dirk Nadon has been with the auction since its start. He reminisced about the work Bailey, his good friend, did since he started the event, raising just over $2,100 out of a radio station van. “He sparked an idea that has now raised almost $10 million,” Nadon said. “How do you compare that with anything?” Debbie Frawley Drake has been volunteering for “many, many years,” and will be at the auction from start to finish. She said watching the community come together is the best part of all. “It makes my heart smile,” she said. “This helps so many kids and brings so much positivity, and we need that more now than ever.” Amy Daley is recently retired, and is not only a new Gilford resident, she is also new to the auction board of directors. She has helped with the Christmas in July cruise on the M/S Mount Washington, as well as selling ornaments, and getting together the Governor’s Island Club’s first ever Pub Mania team. Daley puts an emphasis on children and education when it comes to her charitable giving, and she said the Children’s Auction is the perfect way to give back. “I am having a ball,” Daley said. Larry Poliquin is the store manager for Hannaford in Bristol, which for the fifth year is the presenting sponsor of the event. He is also the vice chair of the board of directors, and serves on the distribution committee, determining how the funds are divvied out. “A lot of people see this as a holiday season kickoff,” said Poliquin, who has been involved in the auction for 20 years. “There’s a lot of anticipation and excitement going on, and we’re just hopeful that the community will come together in a big way like they do each year.” Veronica Rosa, chief advancement officer for Concord Hospital, said for the second straight year, she will be there with her entire senior leadership team. “I’m so excited for this week,” she said. “I love this stuff.” Board member Bob Laraway was looking around the auction headquarters as volunteers ran around, conferring with one another on what was needed to make everything run. Everyone is a cog in a system that will, this week, raise money to assist about 42,000 children in need. “This is purely community driven,” Laraway said. “It’s a labor of love for all of us.” The auction will kick off at 9 a.m. on Tuesday, Dec. 9, with Morrissette saying there will be an unveiling of a dedication to Bailey. “He was able to bring the community together, and that is the whole point every single year, to help kids in need,” Morrissette said. “That is what he was all about. Warren will always be in our hearts." Auction headquarters is at Belknap Marketplace, and the Greater Lakes Region Children's Auction runs 9 a.m.-7 p.m., Tuesday through Friday, Dec. 9-12. It will be broadcast daily on Lakes 101.5 FM, Lakes Region Public Access channels 25 and 9002 on Breezeline, and Comcast Channel 8, and streamed live at laconiadailysun.com and childrensauction.org. Bid by calling 603-527-0999 or at childrensauction.org. Log In Keep it Clean. Please avoid obscene, vulgar, lewd, racist or sexually-oriented language. PLEASE TURN OFF YOUR CAPS LOCK. Don't Threaten. Threats of harming another person will not be tolerated. Be Truthful. Don't knowingly lie about anyone or anything. Be Nice. No racism, sexism or any sort of -ism that is degrading to another person. Be Proactive. Use the 'Report' link on each comment to let us know of abusive posts. Share with Us. We'd love to hear eyewitness accounts, the history behind an article. summary: The 44th Greater Lakes Region Children’s Auction starts on Monday . The annual event has raised more than $9.2 million to help local children since it began . This year is the first event without the founder and the driving force behind the auction .

title: Newcomers help grow roster size for Raider gymastics team
text: Northfield gymnastic captains for 2025-26 are (L-R) Kate Wiber and Tara Alaniz. (Photo by Tom Nelson, Northfield News) The Northfield High School gymnastics team will certainly have a new look this season as the Raider roster will include 10 newcomers along with five returning student-athletes from last year’s team. “As for the strengths of the team, we have more new girls then returners. Some may look at that as a weakness but it really excites me because it allows us to shape the team the way we want it to be," said NHS head coach Zoe Ingersoll, who begins her fifth season as the Raiders’ head coach and seventh season overall with the team. The team has also seen a notable increase in size as last year’s roster size was eight and this year the roster will include the 10 newcomers along with five returners including captains junior Kate Wiebe and senior Tara Alainz along with junior CoCo Shuster, junior Avery Sammon and senior Samantha Pasch. “What I see as a strength is that we have so many different girls here that we have the opportunity to shape our program. Since our team was so small last year, this will be a great opportunity to grow our program and spread the love of gymnastics,” Alainz said. Ingersoll noted the impact that her captains will have on the squad this season as athletes and as team leader. “I’m really excited about the captains and how they are leading the team. When I look for captains each year, I look for people who are born leaders, or are growing to be leaders, and they can change the energy of their team. They don’t have to be the strongest athlete of every event but that they are someone who the team will notice when they are gone.” The Raider coach is happy to see the larger squad size this season and looks forward to working with the new athletes on the team. “A lot of these girls who are joining the high school team I coached in their early club days, so it is fun to get to coach them again, see how much they have grown and how far they will go in high school,” Ingersoll said. “There are a couple of girls coming over to the high school team from different gyms so it has been fun to have them try new things and see what they are able to do. The girls who I have seen before who have come out this year are right on the edge of getting new skills, so it is really fun to see those skills start to go into their routines.” Wiebe talked about what she sees as a strength of this year’s team. “The strengths of this team are our team chemistry, we work hard and that we like to have a lot of fun.” She also provided her insight into being a team captain for the Raiders this season, “I just like to work super hard and want to be a good role model for my teammates, and try to have a positive attitude at all times so it will have a positive effect on the whole team.” Alaniz continued with her thoughts on being a team captain, “I just want to spread that positivity and make sure everyone is having fun and working hard. With all the new girls, our goal is to have fun and make them enjoy the sport more and to see what it is all about.” Fans should expect an evolving lineup for the Raider this season as many of the team’s newcomers gain varsity experience. As Northfield looks ahead to the upcoming season, Owatonna is the reigning state champion and should be a team to beat in both the conference and section. The other top teams to watch in the section include Farmington and Lakeville South. “We have a tough section with a lot of talented teams,” Ingersoll said. The Raiders opened the 2025-26 season on Friday, Dec. 5 with a meet in Rochester against Mayo, John Marshall and Century. Northfield won the quad meet with a score of 126.95, while Century placed second with a score of 122.175 followed by Mayo with 111.25 and John Marshall with 70.1. Ninth grader Evelyn Hubers led the Raiders with a first place score in the All-Around standings of 32.35 followed by Wiebe in second place at 31.975 and Sammon in third place at 31.3. Hubers placed first in the vault competition at 8.8 and teammate sophomore Josie Porter was second at 8.4. Sammon won the beam event with a score of 8.375 followed in second place by Wiebe at 7.875 and Evelyn Podracky in sixth place at 7.5. Sammon also gained a second place finish in the floor event with a score of 8.6 with Hubers in third place at 8.475 and Wiebe in fourth place at 8.4. On the bars, Wiebe led the Raiders with a fourth place score of 7.1 and Hubers was fifth at 7.675 and Pasch was seventh at 7.025. To complete the weekend, Northfield placed eight at the Prior Lake Invitational on Saturday, Dec. 6 with a team score of 130.7. Lakeville South led the meet with a score of 140.1 followed by New Prague (138.7), Prior Lake (137.5), Apple Valley-Eastview (136.65), Lakeville North (136), Farmington (135.15) and Rosemount (133.9). Hubers led Northfield with a 10th place finish in the All-Around and the vault and a 19th place finish in the floor event. Wiebe placed 12th in the All-Around and led NHS with a 15th place finish in the bars. On the beam, Northfield’s Sammon placed ninth at the meet. Northfield will continue its season on Friday, Dec. 19 with a Big 9 dual meet at Faribault. Get any of our free email newsletters — news headlines, e-edition, prep sports, obituaries, entertainment and more. Tom Nelson is a freelance sports reporter for the Northfield News.
summary: The Northfield High School gymnastics team will include 10 newcomers along with five returning student-athletes from last year’s team . Coach Zoe Ingersoll is happy to see the larger squad size this season and looks forward to working with the new athletes .

title: Magnitude 7.5 quake in northern Japan injures 23 people and triggers a tsunami
text: TOKYO (AP) — A powerful 7.5-magnitude earthquake struck off northern Japan late Monday, injuring more than 20 people and triggering a tsunami of up to 70 centimeters (28 inches) in Pacific coast communities, officials said. The Japanese government was still assessing damages from the tsunami and late-evening quake, which struck at about 11:15 p.m. (1415 GMT) in the Pacific Ocean around 80 kilometers (50 miles) off the coast of Aomori, the northernmost prefecture of Japan’s main Honshu island. “I’ve never experienced such a big shaking,” convenience store owner Nobuo Yamada told the public broadcaster NHK in the Aomori prefecture town of Hachinohe, adding that “luckily” power lines were still operating in his area. A tsunami of 70 centimeters was measured in Kuji port in Iwate prefecture, just south of Aomori, and tsunami levels of up to 50 centimeters struck other coastal communities in the region, the Japan Meteorological Agency said. The Fire and Disaster Management Agency said 23 people were injured, including one seriously. Most of the victims were hit by falling objects, NHK reported, adding that several people were injured in a hotel in Hachinohe and a man in Tohoku was slightly hurt when his car fell into a hole. The meteorological agency reported the quake's magnitude as 7.5, down from its earlier estimate of 7.6. It issued an alert for potential tsunami surges of up to 3 meters (10 feet) in some areas and later downgraded to an advisory. Chief Cabinet Secretary Minoru Kihara urged residents to go to higher ground or seek shelter until advisories were lifted. He said about 800 homes were without electricity, and that the Shinkansen bullet trains and some local lines were suspended in parts of the region. Nuclear power plants in the region were conducting safety checks, Kihara said. The Nuclear Regulation Authority said about 450 liters (118 gallons) of water spilled from a spent fuel cooling area at the Rokkasho fuel reprocessing plant in Aomori, but that its water level remained within the normal range and there was no safety concern. About 480 residents were taking shelter at the Hachinohe Air Base, and 18 defense helicopters were mobilized for a damage assessment, Defense Minister Shinjiro Koizumi said. About 200 passengers were stranded for the night at New Chitose Airport in Hokkaido, NHK reported. The meteorological agency issued a caution about possible aftershocks in the coming days. It said there is a slight increase in risk of a magnitude 8-level quake and possible tsunami occurring along Japan's northeastern coast from Chiba, just east of Tokyo, to Hokkaido. The agency urged residents in 182 municipalities in the area to monitor their emergency preparedness in the coming week. Satoshi Kato, a vice principal of a public high school in Hachinohe, told NHK that he was at home when the quake struck, and that glasses and bowls fell and smashed into shards on the floor. Kato said he drove to the school because it was designated an evacuation center, and on the way he encountered traffic jams and car accidents as panicked people tried to flee. Nobody had yet come to the school to take shelter, he said. Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi, in brief comment to reporters, said the government set up an emergency task force to urgently assess the extent of damage. “We are putting people’s lives first and doing everything we can,” she said. Later, she urged residents in the region to pay attention to the latest information from local municipalities. “Please be prepared so you can immediately evacuate as soon as you feel a tremor." The quake struck about 80 kilometers (50 miles) northeast of Hachinohe, and about 50 kilometers (30 miles) below the sea surface, the meteorological agency said. It was just north of the Japanese coast that suffered the magnitude 9.0 quake and tsunami in 2011 that killed nearly 20,000 people. Copyright 2025 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. summary: 7.5-magnitude earthquake strikes off northern Japan late Monday, injuring more than 20 people . Japan Meteorological Agency reports tsunami of up to 70 centimeters (28 inches) in Pacific coast communities . About 800 homes without electricity, Shinkansen bullet trains and some local lines suspended in parts of region .

title: The Gross Law Firm Notifies Shareholders of Synopsys, Inc.(SNPS) of a Class Action Lawsuit and an Upcoming Deadline
text: NEW YORK, Dec. 08, 2025 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- The Gross Law Firm issues the following notice to shareholders of Synopsys, Inc. (NASDAQ: SNPS). Shareholders who purchased shares of SNPS during the class period listed are encouraged to contact the firm regarding possible lead plaintiff appointment. Appointment as lead plaintiff is not required to partake in any recovery. CONTACT US HERE: CLASS PERIOD: December 4, 2024 to September 9, 2025 ALLEGATIONS: The complaint alleges that during the class period, Defendants issued materially false and/or misleading statements and/or failed to disclose that: (1) the extent to which the Company’s increased focus on artificial intelligence customers, which require additional customization, was deteriorating the economics of its Design IP business; (2) that, as a result, “certain road map and resource decisions” were unlikely to “yield their intended results;” (3) that the foregoing had a material negative impact on financial results; and (4) that, as a result of the foregoing, defendants’ positive statements about the Company’s business, operations, and prospects were materially misleading and/or lacked a reasonable basis. DEADLINE: December 30, 2025 Shareholders should not delay in registering for this class action. Register your information here: NEXT STEPS FOR SHAREHOLDERS: Once you register as a shareholder who purchased shares of SNPS during the timeframe listed above, you will be enrolled in a portfolio monitoring software to provide you with status updates throughout the lifecycle of the case. The deadline to seek to be a lead plaintiff is December 30, 2025. There is no cost or obligation to you to participate in this case. WHY GROSS LAW FIRM? The Gross Law Firm is a nationally recognized class action law firm, and our mission is to protect the rights of all investors who have suffered as a result of deceit, fraud, and illegal business practices. The Gross Law Firm is committed to ensuring that companies adhere to responsible business practices and engage in good corporate citizenship. The firm seeks recovery on behalf of investors who incurred losses when false and/or misleading statements or the omission of material information by a company lead to artificial inflation of the company's stock. Attorney advertising. Prior results do not guarantee similar outcomes. CONTACT:The Gross Law Firm15 West 38th Street, 12th floorNew York, NY, 10018Email: dg@securitiesclasslaw.comPhone: (646) 453-8903
summary: The Gross Law Firm issues the following notice to shareholders of Synopsys, Inc. (NASDAQ: SNPS) Shareholders who purchased shares of SNPS during the class period listed are encouraged to contact the firm regarding possible lead plaintiff appointment . There is no cost or obligation to you to participate in this case .

title: When is the next Mercadona opening in Portugal?
text: The Spanish Mercadona supermarket group will open its second store in the city of Lisbon during the first quarter of 2026. By TPN, in News, Business, Portugal, Lisbon · 08 Dec 2025, 20:08 · 0 Comments Mercadona opened its first supermarket in the city of Lisbon this month, but it will not stop there. The Spanish group intends to open its second establishment in the capital during the first quarter of 2026, by March, and thus reach 70 stores in the national territory, according to a report by NM. "In the first quarter of 2026, the company will open its second store in the city, in Quinta do Lambert (Lumiar), reaching the milestone of 70 stores in the country," reads a statement released by the company. This announcement came at the time when Mercadona opened its first store in Lisbon, located in Alta de Lisboa, on Rua Hermínio da Palma Inácio. The company considered that "this is an important step in the company's expansion plan in Portugal, which now brings it closer to the 'Bosses' (customers) who have long requested a store in the capital." "The Mercadona in Alta de Lisboa, the 9th in the district, has created 90 new, stable, and high-quality jobs with permanent contracts from day one," the statement also reads. The company revealed that the establishment "has a sales area of ​​1900 m2 and includes the following sections: Butcher, Fishmonger, Delicatessen, Pastry and Bakery, Perfumery, Home Care and Pets, Fruits and Vegetables, Wine Cellar, and Ready-to-Eat with self-service and various options of prepared dishes to take away or eat in the store, in an exclusive area for this purpose." "It has 300 parking spaces, including 6 designated for charging electric vehicles, fulfilling the company's commitment to electric mobility," the statement also reads. Furthermore, "within its Social Action plan, and as is the case in all stores in the chain, Mercadona will donate essential goods to the Musgueira Social Center from day one." Share this article: Share
summary: The Spanish Mercadona supermarket group will open its second store in the city of Lisbon during the first quarter of 2026 . The company considered that "this is an important step in the company's expansion plan in Portugal"
